AAN-6693.description:
On parle beaucoup de r√©flexion en Java/Kotlin et je vous l‚Äôaccorde c‚Äôest assez marrant √† coder. Mais son utilisation n‚Äôest pas gratuite, augmentation de la m√©moire, ralentissement de l‚Äôapplication et magie vaudou sont 3 bonnes raisons pour envisager de s‚Äôen passer.

En utilisant les annotations processors (apt ou kapt) nous pouvons faire g√©n√©rer du code √† la compilation. Cela aura pour effet de rendre visible la magie, et donc de la d√©mystifier tout en rattrapant les lenteurs caus√©es par la r√©flexion.

Dans la g√©n√©ration de code, le plus compliqu√© c'est de se lancer. Je vous invite √† d√©couvrir cela dans un contexte sans risque, nous serons l√† pour toute explication/question.

√âquip√© de votre plus bel IntelliJ, vous d√©velopperez votre premier moteur d'injection de d√©pendances bas√© sur annotations.**

Ce sera aussi l'occasion de faire du Kotlin, et de d√©couvrir KPoet (https://github.com/agrosner/KPoet) l'ami des g√©n√©rateurs de code.

ADK-5240.description: This session will be about how to create custom machine learning models with AutoML and using these models within your mobile app through firebase cloud functions.
ADK-5240.title: Using AutoML custom models in your mobile app

ADV-3387.description:
Unit, integration, UI tests are part of the famous test pyramid, different tools were used in order to full fill it, but still today there are lot of issues about how to execute it in a proper manner and how to sync all environments (local, ci, etc) in order to satisfy all the testing criteria, and having a good reports.

From IO 2018 with the announcement of project Nitrogen, Google'd like to "nitrogenize" our tests creating a single entry point and solve all issues
we had in the past. With October release of Robolectric 4.0 and androidx.test 1.0.0, both testing environments are converging on a set of common test APIs. Robolectric now supports the AndroidJUnit4 test runner, ActivityTestRule, and Espresso for interacting with UI components.

Let's see togheter how to organise different levels of our 'test pyramid', with a focus to the last news/releases in order ot be ready for the Nitrogen release.
ADV-3387.title: Nitrogen in your (test) pyramid.

AFF-5103.description:
The first question Android developers ask me when they learn that I do talks about the Google Assistant is: *"OH! I have this awesome app that has this use case and I totally want to integrate it with the Google Assistant so I can do hands-free actions inside my app"*. This is a genuine question with a complicated answer. 

There are several tools out there that you can use to address this problem: Dialogflow, TensorFlow (Mobile, Lite), ML Kit, Cloud APIs, Auto ML. The most impressive thing? They're all Google solutions! If you're not confused yet, take a look at Google Maps that "integrated" with the Google Assistant when you're in itinerary mode and App Actions that are supposed to help Android developers take advantage of Actions on Google.

In this talk, I'm *not* talking about integrating your app with the Google Assistant, but rather how Android developers can add voice actions in their app (not via the Google Assistant). I'll then talk about both ecosystems (Android and Assistant) and how they interact with each other.
AFF-5103.title: Integrating Android with the Google Assistant

AMU-5195.description:
After TensorFlow Lite, MLKit  promises to be our new tool to make our apps smarter. The possibility to integrate our model directly on Firebase is crazy, but the second part (often put aside) deserves our attention.
Based in majority on deprecated Mobile Vision, the few models offered by Google already give us something to enjoy. Most of them is available offline: so we can imagine the extent of the possibilities!

Come with me to discover these APIs: how and why to use them.

Apres TensorFlow Lite, ML Kit s‚Äôannonce √™tre notre nouvel outil pour rendre nos apps intelligentes. La possibilit√© d‚Äôh√©berger nos mod√®les sur Firebase est d√©j√† folle, mais la seconde partie (souvent vite vu) m√©rite notre attention. 
Bas√©e en grande partie sur feu-Mobile Vision, les quelques mod√®les propos√©s par Google nous donnent d√©j√† de quoi nous amuser. La plupart sont disponible offline: on peut donc imaginer l‚Äô√©tendue des possibilit√©s!

Je vous propose de m‚Äôaccompagner dans la d√©couverte de ces API: comment et pourquoi les utiliser.
AMU-5195.title: Do you want an easy way to add Machine Learning into your app?

ASC-4315.description:
Are you an Android developer? Do you have huge monolithic fragments in your code? Are there too many non-testable classes? Are you faced with poor code coverages? Doesn‚Äôt this sound like a familiar story in Android app engineering? Kotlin Clean Code can help you solve these problems and improve the developer experience.

In this experiential talk, Mohanraj Karatadipalayam gives you a detailed overview of Kotlin Clean Code  For Android, that enables the developers to write clean code, that has a good degree of separation of concerns and testability. He explores in detail, the need for Kotlin Clean Code for Android that makes programming more predictable. Using real examples and code snippets, Mohan highlights key challenges encountered while writing such apps and how he overcame them.
ASC-4315.title: Kotlin Clean Code for Android

BDO-0366.description:
This talk will give you the tools to prepare for interviews, whether it‚Äôs making your hiring process better, or simply preparing for an interview as an Android developer. Hiring and interviewing is not easy, and there is no easy solution to it. But we hope that with this talk we would make it a little bit better for everyone involved.

With this talk we want to show you behind the scenes of the interviewing process, to make it feel less intimidating. We want to teach you how to choose a job and a company that fits with your requirements. We also want to give some tips on how to prepare for interviews, and the sort of exercises you might encounter.

We also want to help companies improve their hiring process, because we think there is room for improvement. There is no solution that works for everyone, but there are patterns everyone can follow to do better. We want to show you how to reach candidates, make sure qualified candidates apply, show you how to deal with the unavoidable biases you will face.

Hiring and interviewing is not easy, and there is no easy solution to it. But we hope that with this talk we would make it a little bit better for everyone involved.
BDO-0366.title: Hire Better Faster Stronger

BFM-7462.description: Armed with tools like Arcore & Sceneform, A/R is now a reality on Android. Come ready to learn how easy it is to add augmented reality features to your apps. By the end of the session you'll know how to make your own models and how to get them into your app. I'll be going over creating scenes with lights & animation, plane detection & using targets to make real life objects come to life. No prior 3D or A/R experience is necessary.
BFM-7462.title: 0 to AR

BFO-2106.description:
Attend this _real life_ workshop to start augmenting reality! We will use ARCore and Sceneform to create an AR Stickers application. Learn how to:

- Setup ARCore and Sceneform in an Android app and start a session to display the camera feed and gather data about the environment around a device
- Control nodes within a scene graph in order to place 3D objects that are anchored to points in the real world
- Use the Sceneform plugin to import and manage 3D models
- Handle interactions like clicks and drags to move objects around

We will provide a step-by-step overview to get you started, guidance throughout the workshop, and 3D models that can be included in your scenes. 

Come with a laptop (or one to share); Android Studio 3.1+ w/ Android SDK 24+; Android Emulator 27.2.9+ or ARCore supported device.

*About ARCore and Sceneform*

ARCore is a library that combines motion tracking, environmental understanding, and light estimation data to enable building AR experiences more easily on Android. 

Sceneform is a library that provides tooling to render 3D models. It includes a high-level scene graph API, a physically based renderer called Filament, and a plugin for editing 3D models.
BFO-2106.title: Augmented Reality Workshop: Getting Started with ARCore and Sceneform

BLY-1248.description:
Machine Learning est un mot cl√© que personne n'a pu ignorer ces derniers temps. Cette technologie permet d'entra√Æner un logiciel √† une t√¢che afin de le rendre autonome par la suite. 
Reconnaissance de texte, d√©tection de visages, scan de codes barres, reconnaissance d'images, de marques, .. toutes ces fonctionnalit√©s font r√™ver d√©veloppeurs comme clients mais les comp√©tences √† avoir semblent souvent hors de port√©e ou trop ch√®res.

Et si je vous disais que vous pouvez impl√©menter les fonctionnalit√©s cit√©es ci-dessus sans avoir d'expertise en Machine Learning ?

MLKit est une solution propos√©e par Google via Firebase permettant d'√©carter ce manque d'expertise afin de se concentrer sur l'important. Il n'est alors plus n√©c√©ssaire d'√™tre un expert en Machine Learning pour impl√©menter les fonctionnalit√©s qui nous font r√™ver et qui donneront une grande valeur ajout√©e √† nos applications.

Avec un mode "on-device", MLKit rend m√™me accessible la plupart de ces fonctionnalit√©s en mode hors-ligne.

Rendre votre application accessible via d√©tection de visage, scanner des codes bars et analyser du texte.. Le monde du Machine Learning s'ouvre √† vous !
BLY-1248.title: Ajoutez facilement du Machine Learning dans votre application mobile !

BMT-4921.description: Want to know the standards and best practices Googlers followed while building their annual Android app? This session is for you, where we will decode everything they wrote! Right from why they choose Clean Architecture to the tools and libraries used by them to make Google I/O Android App more flexible for developers and easy to use for attendees.
BMT-4921.title: Decoding Google I/O Android App 2018

BOP-1045.description:
Dagger is a dependency injection library originally developed by square but now maintained by Google. Dagger creates and maintains an acyclic object graph of instances and injects them either as variables or constructor parameters wherever they are needed. 
Dagger also provides one with the ability to define the life cycle of an injected variable through a methodology called scoping. 

This talk will be a deep dive into dependency injection with dagger and I'll cover a lot of grounds including getting started, avoiding common errors and tips and tricks for DI on Android.
BOP-1045.title: Architecting your dependencies with Dagger.

BQP-2138.description:
Tofus (‚ñ°) are representations used when a specific character (like an Emoji) cannot be displayed. You have seen them, and so your users. Thanks to EmojiCompat, now Android developers have a way to provide Emoji compatibility for older devices, but does it solve all the issues developers have with Emoji? 

Have you wondered why apps count characters differently depending on the Emoji? Or how gender and skin tone Emoji modifiers work? How can I have a similar functionality as Slack on my app with custom Emoji? Do all your users see the same Emoji? On this talk, you will learn about the different pitfalls developers face when working with Emoji, like code points, the Fitzpatrick modifiers and short-names, you will learn how to use EmojiCompat and I will show you alternatives to it.

In this talk you will learn:
- What are the problems developers face with Emoji
- How Emoji works
- How to use EmojiCompat including dynamic font downloading
- What is EmojiCompat not solving, and what can you do
- What alternatives are there to EmojiCompat

After this talk, you will be an Emoji expert, no longer afraid of showing ‚ñ° (tofu) to your users!
BQP-2138.title: No More ‚ñ° ‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää Mastering Emoji on Android

BUD-3852.description:
Avec les extensions, les optionnels, les data class, etc. Kotlin est devenu pour beaucoup de d√©veloppeurs Android totalement incontournable. Arriv√©es plus tard √† maturit√© et encore trop peu usit√©es, nous allons montrer que les Coroutines m√©ritent elles aussi une place de choix dans nos d√©veloppement.

Cette pr√©sentation s'efforcera de montrer comment les Coroutines fonctionnent, mais plus particuli√®rement _comment_ appliquer leur principe aux diff√©rents cas d'usage que l'on peut rencontrer en Android : 
- Remplacer une AsyncTask
- Faire des appels r√©seaux asynchrones
- Mettre un d√©lai sur une requ√™te dans l'attente d'autres informations
- √âviter un encha√Ænement de callbacks et de broadcasts et cr√©er du code asynchrone _mais_ cod√© de fa√ßon s√©quentielle.

Le but est de d√©mystifier les Coroutines - en n'insistant pas sur la partie th√©orique - et de montrer via des exemples concrets et courants comment celles-ci vont nous faciliter notre vie de d√©veloppeur dans les ann√©es √† venir.
BUD-3852.title: Comment passer aux coroutines avec Kotlin

BWG-4398.description:
The diamond inheritance problem (needing a class to inherit from more than one super class) has always been a frustrating problem, which in Android often means we have to repeat code more often than we'd like. I find this often to be the case with implementing multiple screens with shared elements and functions. Ultimately, inheritance isn‚Äôt flexible enough to handle all the mixing and matching we often have to do.

Functions, though, are. In this talk, I‚Äôll discuss how using a small bit of functional programming can reap massive benefits in your code.
BWG-4398.title: Diamond in the rough: overcoming diamond inheritance with functions

BXQ-5942.description: Android is a marvelous platform that has been evolving for more than 10 years now. Having such a large framework and so many APIs, some of thme comes with their questions and puzzlers. In this talk, we will present some of the weirdest API usage/results and give an explanation for each of them.
BXQ-5942.title: Android Puzzlers

CEF-1607.description:
Library maintenance is a fun, terrible, exciting, daunting, nuanced, and interesting line of work. Sometimes you‚Äôre the janitor and sometimes you‚Äôre the surgeon. This talk is about lessons learned over the years of doing core librarian work in open source and on a big team. From API design to engaging dogma, we‚Äôll dive into the many facets of maintaining a codebase‚Äôs foundations and the community that grows around it, and how to leverage them for a better developer experience for everyone.

Oh, and tombstone cakes.
CEF-1607.title: Lessons from a Librarian

CFP-0648.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. CFP-0648.title: Super Talk

CRB-1281.description:
The journey from power up to home screen is surprisingly complex. In this talk I will give you some insight into the twists and turns.

Everything starts with the bootloader, which is responsible for basic hardware initialization and loading the Linux kernel. Once Linux is in charge, the remainder of the system can be set up and the first program, called init, can be started. At this point I will look at the way init reads various script files and starts all the native services (also known as daemons).

Init starts the prototype Java runtime, known as the Zygote. The first instance of the Zygote runs the System Server, which is a container for the most important services that make up the Android framework. One of those services is the Activity Manager. This is the component which starts Android applications, beginning with those that have the persistent property, then the Home App, and finally sending  the BOOT_COMPLETED intent to kick off all other apps that want to start at boot.

I will illustrate all of the above with code samples and walk-throughs to illustrate how you can make changes to customize each step.
CRB-1281.title: From power-on to Home App: what happens during boot

CRY-8750.description:
Have you dreamed of deliciously sweet animations in your app but have no idea where to start? üç´ What about creating some delightful UI treats to keep your users intrigued and wanting to discover more? üç¶
Join Rebecca on this journey into a World of Pure Android Animation ‚ú®.  From creating custom view animations on a Canvas to using MotionLayout to create complex layout animations, there is something for everyone. We will also see how to create your own AnimatedVectorDrawable using Shape Shifter. No golden ticket required.
CRY-8750.title: In a World of Pure Android Animation  üç≠üç´

CSH-2746.description:
Performance testing has always been neglected by developers. We write unit tests and integration tests but for some reason we never test the performance of our apps and when we do is already too late because our users are complaining about it. It has not been historically easy to write these tests and we usually rely on manual testing, which is not really accurate, or complicated tools that we don‚Äôt even know how to use or we don‚Äôt understand. But, is there an easy way to write and automate performance tests? Yes there is, and I‚Äôm going to show you how you can do it. 

In this talk you will learn how you can write and automate performance tests for your Android apps. We will explore different ways of writing performance tests and we will see how we can take advantage of a few not well-known APIs that the Android platform offer us to help us in our journey towards the perfect automation testing suite.
CSH-2746.title: Writing and Automating Performance Tests in Android

CZW-2380.description: An introduction to the Model View Intent architecture pattern. This pattern takes ideas and concepts from Reactive and Functional programming. We'll go over the core principles of this pattern, and how you can apply them in your Android applications. We'll look at concrete implementation details, and explore some of its benefits. Some familiarity with Kotlin and RxJava is assumed.
CZW-2380.title: Simple MVI Architecture for Android

DAP-7739.description:
Nous vous proposons d'utiliser tous vos outils Android pr√©f√©r√©s dans un live coding pour cr√©er un jeu de questions/r√©ponses grandeur nature, avec un animateur unique : Pepper le robot.

Au menu : Kotlin, Gradle, Firebase, Android Things et n'oublions pas Pepper et son SDK Android !
Ce talk sera accompagn√© de plusieurs d√©monstrations, qui permettront de vous montrer quelques fonctionnalit√©s offertes par le SDK de Pepper : d√©tection d'humains, d√©placement, discussion.

Nous vous donnerons toutes les pistes pour cr√©er vos propres applications robotiques et exploiter √† fond le potentiel de Pepper : le robot pour les d√©veloppeurs Android.
DAP-7739.title: [Live coding] Pepper + Android + IoT = 1 jeu connect√©

DAX-8321.description:
Back in the days, your application was a charm, clean, designed, the code was clear, and at any point in time, you could tell in which state it was. But over time, new features came into play, network calls, asynchronous processing, your little baby turned out to be a monster and you loose yourself in the code, it‚Äôs not possible to tell in which state your app is between network calls, errors, user interactions, etc.. You‚Äôre lost !

Grox is an open source library (https://github.com/groupon/grox) that helps to manage the state of Kotlin / Java / Android applications. Inspired by Flux and Redux, Grox lets you express state changes in a testable and homogenous way. Grox offers a flexible, scalable way to manage the state of your application. With Grox you know in which exact state you are at any point in time, and you state will be represented clearly. Grox also offers time travel debugging, and a nice Rx API that plays very well with RxBinding and asynchronous code. 

In this session, we will explain why Grox is nice, give a few examples to use it, test your code and enjoy it‚Äôs scalability. You will see that Grox is a breeze to manage from the simplest app to the most complex ones.
DAX-8321.title: Grox: a library to manage the state of Java / Android apps

DCF-5057.description:
In 2018 Android App Bundles were introduced as the publishing format for Android. Alongside this dynamic delivery enable shipping features to users on demand.
In this session you'll learn about Android App Bundles, Dynamic Delivery and how to structure code and resources based on publicly available code samples.
Also you'll learn how to make an instant experience available for your app.
DCF-5057.title: Best practices for a modularized app

DFO-2916.description:
Functions that take a long time to return are a problem because they block the calling thread, which could be the main thread, where your UI runs.
You can workaround this issue by using callbacks instead, but it introduces other issues:

- Mangled functions signatures
- Inability to use even simple language constructs like `if`, `while` or local variables
- More verbose usage (boilerplate never scales well)
- Harder error/exception handling

Seeing it brings more problems than it solves helps us understand why people refer to **callback hells**.

There's been attempts to circumvent these issues with AsyncTask (no comment), Futures (from JDK, Guava, and more), Tasks API (from Google Play Services), reactive programming (e.g. RxJava used for threading and callbacks), and none solves all the issues mentioned above.

**Kotlin coroutines are changing the game** with an implementation of the nearly 60 years old concept that **brings back the simplicity of blocking code**, without the blocking issue.

In this talk, you'll see how any waiting or blocking code can be made easier to write and read.
You'll learn how to use kotlinx.coroutines correctly in Android, and peek at how it all works.
DFO-2916.title: Making any codebase more readable with Kotlin coroutines

DNR-5013.description:
From principles to implementation, the new Navigation Architecture Component helps to design the interactions that allow users to navigate across, into, and back out from the different pieces of content within the app.
Renaud will explore the basics and then dive into specific use cases such as deep-linking, manipulating the back-stack or even providing safe arguments.
DNR-5013.title: Designing effective navigation

DOJ-4275.description:
J'aime avoir confiance dans le code que je livre en production, mais qu'en est-il du code g√©n√©r√© par le compilateur ?

Le code g√©n√©r√© est une technique pour s'affranchir de la r√©flexion √† l'ex√©cution, elle est grandement utilis√©e dans les environnements √† ressources limit√©es comme des applications mobiles. En effet la r√©flexion est une technologie co√ªteuse en temps et en m√©moire.

En Kotlin, tout comme en Java, les annotations processors (par exemple apt/kapt) g√©n√®rent du code √† la compilation en analysant les annotations contenues dans le code. Quel m√©canisme se cache derri√®re cette g√©n√©ration, et √† quoi ressemble du code g√©n√©r√© ? Regardons ensemble l'envers du d√©cor d'une biblioth√®que d'injection de d√©pendances.

Nous verrons ainsi les √©tapes √† suivre pour cr√©er notre propre g√©n√©rateur en utilisant des annotations.
DOJ-4275.title: G√©n√©ration de code, la face cach√©e du boilerplate

DOU-0750.description:
During a vacation, I have wanted to play a blitz chess game with a friend. We only had a chess board with us, but no chess clock. We looked for Android apps online, but none satisfied us.
Hence, in February 2017 I have started writing a chess clock app for Android. In the beginning, the app got 0 to 5 installs per day. With time and some tricks, more and more user installed it.
Now after almost two years 400 to 650 new users are installing the app every day; without a single dime spent on marketing. Daily active users are around 1500, weekly around 8500, monthly around 27000 users and it keeps on growing.
I will walk you through my journey step by step. Everything started with research. Development of the app was next. Followed by user acquisition.
Many tricks and tools have helped me to stay sane and focus along the way and will help you in making your application more successful too.
DOU-0750.title: Side project succeeded from 0 to 400+ daily new users

DRD-4155.description:
We‚Äôve all heard it before: watch your APK size, because users avoid downloading apps that seem too large. According to research from Google, there‚Äôs a 1% decrease in the install conversion rate for every 6 MB increase in APK size.

Large apps can be problematic for developers too: as new features are introduced in your app, the basic Android project structure provides little guidance for how to best organize and modularize your growing codebase.

Android App Bundles can help us address both of these problems. App Bundles are an upload format that helps serve your users with targeted APKs. They also expose the ability to use Dynamic Feature Modules, which provide a pattern for developers to architect large apps in a way that keeps features modularized.

- Learn how you can quickly start leveraging App Bundles today to deliver smaller APKs, with no need to refactor your existing project

- Dive deeper into Dynamic Feature Modules to see how separating features from your base module can promote a manageable architecture and allow you to deliver new features to users post-install

- See how to combine with Google Play Instant, allowing users to try without downloading and installing
DRD-4155.title: Bundle Up! Deliver Features On Demand with Android App Bundles

DWT-4436.description:
What does the P stand for in Android P? Protection? Privacy? Or maybe Plethora of security enhancements? This talk will give you a concise update on these new security features, flag any breaking changes when targeting P as well as practical tips and examples of how to improve your app‚Äôs security.

Scott will explore the major changes to the way background apps are restricted from accessing the microphone, camera, and sensors and how to stay on the right side of these privacy restrictions. Google have continued to enhance Network Security Config which now defaults to blocking non-https traffic. As well discussing the restrictions to device serial access, world-accessible files and cryptographic changes. The Keystore also gets enhancements with the ability to import keys and support for a new Hardware security module.
DWT-4436.title: What's New in Android P Security?

EFV-3171.description:
Material Design recommends building a world that is alive, responsive and natural. If meaningful transitions help achieve this material dream, then gestures compliment them. Gestures feel natural to use because they relate with the physical world. Most important of all ‚Äî gestures are downright enjoyable. 

This talk cover,

- How touch events flow through the View hierarchy

- How ViewGroups intercept touch events before the events reach their child Views

- How nested scrollable layouts coordinate with each other

- Walk through building scroll gestures effortlessly with the new nested scrolling APIs.

- How RecyclerView gestures can be created using GestureDetector and other APIs provided out-of-the-box by Android.
EFV-3171.title: Effortless gestures with nested scrolling

EHB-6826.description:
You're right, that title seems scary: there are so many complicated words and we all know there's no silver bullet in programming.

So instead of explaining why an architecture is better than another, let's discuss some issues we face in our daily Android development job and how we can solve those through 3 examples:

1. I have crashes I can't reproduce.
2. Integration tests are great and necessary to ensure a complete flow is working as expected, but they are complex to set up, and it takes time to run the whole test suite when using an instrumentation tool such as Espresso
3. My legacy app has some "startActivity" calls in activites, fragments, custom views, and even in RecyclerView adapters (who did that !?!). I have no visibility regarding the overall navigation of and the code is sometimes hard to follow.

We will see today the concepts underneath and how such an architecture can be implemented using functional programming patterns through writing a Kotlin DSL.

At the end of the talk, you will get a new, fresh, vision on how to approach programming on Android, through a unidirectional data flow structure, and maybe you'll be interested in implementing a similar architecture.
EHB-6826.title: The Rise Of The State Machines: An introduction to predictable state container based architectures for your Android apps

EIT-2929.description:
Defining the styles and themes of an Android application is hard. There are several ways to do it and all of them give you the same outcome, Views and Activity will have the proper appearance. Things get even more complicated when you start working with a codebase that has previously defined styles and themes. Should you refactor? Follow the previous path? Start from scratch?

When it comes to resources things get even more complicated. Should I have one strings file? What about colors and dimensions, and their names... what about their names?!

Fear not, this talk will show you that there is still hope! We'll discuss several ways of organising this mess, so that the next time you have to create a new screen or component, achieving the desired appearance will be the easiest part of the job.
EIT-2929.title: Working effectively with Android styles, themes and resources

EKI-9890.description:
Vim, created 27 years ago, is still one of the most popular text editors for developers. Its major attractive is modal editing: switch from editing text to running commands with a keypress. This allows for precise declarative editing, resting your hands in the keyboard, without having to reach out your mouse.

Learning Vim is not easy, but it is a skill that we can carry all our career as developers, as many IDE and editors support vi-mode. Thanks to IdeaVim, we Android developers can also enjoy modal editing in Android Studio.

In this talk, I will introduce you to Vim and modal editing. You will learn the basic actions, cursor movements, how to configure IdeaVim for your needs, and some of the tricks that helped learn and fall in love with it. I will teach you to adopt Vim as your command line editor, for things like editing git commits and quickly changing configuration files.

After this talk, you will be able to start using Vim and IdeaVim, and enjoy many of the advantages of mouseless development without changing your favorite IDE.
EKI-9890.title: Mouseless development with IdeaVim

EOD-6284.description:
As engineers, we easily default to the idea that becoming experts in our field is the only reasonable way of progressing with our careers. But who will oversee that our career is developing in the right direction? Who makes sure that, may a tension arise within the team, it is resolved in the quickest and most effective way possible? Could that person... could that be you?

Join me as I walk you through my decision to try the Engineering Management career path, and the fresh feedback of my first 6 months in. We will explore the myth (or reality?) of "the manager who codes", how different (or similar?) the role is to a "regular" Software Engineer, and see what skills from your previous role you will need to have, and which new ones you'll need to build up.

Come find out if the cliches about playing golf and spending all day on emails and spreadsheets are true or not! üë©‚Äçüíªüë®‚Äçüíª
EOD-6284.title: From managing code dependencies to managing people

EPD-4464.description:
‚ÄúAny sufficiently advanced technology UI is indistinguishable from magic.‚Äù

Animations and UI interactions are like magic. They bring delight to users, and often rely on deceiving the user by creating illusions that are difficult to spot at 60 frames per second. Cross-fading layers, clipping drawing canvas, playing with elevation, etc. ‚Äî the basic building blocks behind creating these illusions are usually the same. 

This talk aims to cover these basic ideas by using some solid examples of UI interactions that look complex at first, but are actually easy to implement and understand once they‚Äôre broken down.
EPD-4464.title: Smoke & Mirrors

EZW-1827.description:
While most developers are elated when Android Studio compiles their code without any ‚Äúhiccups‚Äù, there is a lot going on when that compiled code runs on Android OS. Android mostly takes care of runtime, but it‚Äôs always nice to know what‚Äôs happening backstage.
How code executes at runtime is a completely different story in case of Android. The .dex format has been here for years and everyone is accustomed to it. But there are a lot of complexities going on once the .dex reaches your device. This talk will focussed on analyzing on what happens after your code in Kotlin/Java is compiled, packaged and run on an actual device. We will take a deep dive into .dex format as well as see how runtime has evolved since Android 1.0 and taken a great leap with Android 5.0 and above. In the process, we will also learn how to write runtime efficient code.
EZW-1827.title: Decoding Android Runtime

FAV-3558.description:
Simple living, often called Minimalism, is a lifestyle that encompasses practices to have a more meaningful life with less. Minimalism in computing is not a novel idea, it existed back in the 80s when the resources were very expensive and limited.

Nowadays, our software development processes seem to have forgot about it. We deploy entire frameworks, or even entire operating systems, to perform a single task. We include libraries in our projects even when we just need a single method. We create bloated products that cram as much features as we can, rather than focusing on doing one thing right. As well, we have problems focusing at work, we struggle to get things done, and all together our mental health is not improving.

I believe that is all related, that we should take a step back, simplify, start small, and declutter.

Come and learn about the principles of minimalism, and how to apply them to your personal and professional life. You will learn about the importance of keeping things simple, learning to focus on the things that matter to make a positive impact in yours, your team‚Äôs and your users' lives.
FAV-3558.title: Minimalism Driven Development

FGQ-3294.description:
In the web world, developers can ship and iterate on features very quickly. How can mobile developers use this same process when there is overhead to doing a full release?

Learn how our team does iterative product development, from technical automation solutions to a team process that facilitates it. You'll learn how developers can gain control and bring features to your customers more quickly!
FGQ-3294.title: Iterative Mobile Development

FHH-4108.description:
Getting started with machine learning on the mobile platform can be daunting. From learning how to implement low-level models and use frameworks, to optimizing and adapting those models for mobile, it can be overwhelming. With ML Kit, regardless of one‚Äôs machine learning expertise, one can build compelling machine learning functionality into their mobile apps. Using ML Kit and Flutter, which is Google‚Äôs mobile SDK for building native Android and iOS apps from a single codebase, one can build apps with machine learning capabilities like face detection and image labeling, for both Android and iOS platforms in record time!

This talk will be guided by the following objectives:

- An introduction to Flutter and to ML Kit

- Determining how to use Flutter to leverage ML Kit‚Äôs functionalities

- Exploring ML Kit‚Äôs on-device features that are currently available, which are text recognition, face detection, barcode scanning and image labeling.

- Equipping attendees with the knowledge they need to build a smart Flutter application with ML Kit.
FHH-4108.title: Flutter + ML Kit: Building smart cross-platform apps

FKX-7445.description: In 2018, I traveled to Guin√©e Conakry in West Africa to help organize a community tech conference and two-day Android development workshop. Later that year, we held the first ever GDG DevFest Conakry, where I gave an introduction to testing on Android. This talk will share highlights and insights from my experience, including giving my first tech in French. We'll also explore the unique challenges and opportunities of creating mobile applications for developing markets.
FKX-7445.title: Quoi de neuf : Guin√©e Conakry

FOS-9087.description:
La navigation au sein d'une application mobile est une partie cruciale de l'exp√©rience utilisateur. Or, nous savons que cela peut souvent se r√©v√©ler un v√©ritable cauchemar de parcourir les diff√©rents Fragments, se passer des donn√©es ou de maintenir une backstack correcte. Et nous passerons sur les crashs et les NullPointerExceptions.

L'ensemble de ces probl√®mes bien connus a √©t√© pris √† bras le corps par Google, qui propose dans Jetpack la biblioth√®que Navigation.

La promesse de Navigation est de simplifier la mise en place de celle-ci. Cette promesse est faite tant sur plan de la personnalisation des transitions, des arguments d'ouverture de fragment, de l'utilisation de liens profonds mais √©galement de la pr√©vention de crashs √©ventuels. Navigation permet aussi d'impl√©menter de mani√®re intuitive le Single Activity App pattern pouss√© par la communaut√©.

La version 3.3 d'Android Studio int√®gre nativement un √©diteur graphique (fa√ßon StoryBoard iOS) afin de cr√©er, lier et visualiser les diff√©rents √©crans de l'application.

Pendant cette pr√©sentation, nous verrons comment utiliser la biblioth√®que Navigation afin d'am√©liorer la lisibilit√© et la maintenabilit√© de nos applications.
FOS-9087.title: Ne plus ramer pour voguer sur Android gr√¢ce √† Navigation!

FPG-0301.description:
We all know that software is usually not free of bugs. Monitoring your backend systems and having error logging mechanism for them is reasonably common nowadays. Logging issues in client-side apps is usually more complicated and requires some planning and usually additional libraries. Ideally you‚Äôd be able to track and follow issues across your tech stack and be notified of critical problems. All of these requirements fall under the bigger umbrella of APM (Application Performance Management)

For Android, there are a variety of solutions around that cater for the above setup to different degrees. There‚Äôs Firebase Crashlytics and Performance Monitoring, Instabug, Appdynamics, Raygun and many others.

This talk provides an introduction into APM from the point of view of an Android, Javascript and backend developer. We‚Äôll discuss common product features, their usage patterns and best practices for setting up integration libraries into your apps. The session will also cover typical organisational concerns such as perceived performance overhead or cost and how to counter and debunk these myths by looking at the benefits of a comprehensive error logging solution.
FPG-0301.title: Crushing bugs in Android and across your stack

FTR-0446.description: Join this session to get a deep dive into the use of Jetpack‚Äôs Android Architecture Components along with Firebase to keep your app‚Äôs data fully synchronized and automatically refreshed with live updates from Realtime Database and Firestore.  Bring an Android device to participate in a live demo!
FTR-0446.title: Firebase and Android Jetpack: fit like a glove

FVG-0559.description:
Hiring the right people is hard. Hiring a diverse set of the right people is even harder ‚Äì or so many believe. 

As tech struggles with issues of bias and representation, one step in the right direction may be to learn a lesson from an unlikely source: orchestras. In the 70s and 80s, classical orchestras moved to a blind audition model when hiring musicians, and subsequently had a spike in female and minority members. 

This talk will discuss some ways to implement this process at your company, allowing you to accurately evaluate diverse, highly qualified applicants. We‚Äôll highlight some of the difficulties and pitfalls you might encounter, as well as the benefits you can reap.
FVG-0559.title: How to implement a "blind audition" hiring model for Android devs

FVI-2317.description:
Kotlin offers many powerful language features that make it a welcome addition to the Android developer's toolkit.
But some of these features may do significant work behind the scenes, including allocating object and reflection. This dynamic is not obvious from the Kotlin code, so how do we know when this is happening?
This talk will go over some of these areas that you should be aware of, as well as the tools that help us discover this kind of information about our code.
FVI-2317.title: Kotlin Under the Covers

FWP-0664.description:
Code reviews are a fundamental part of our job as software developers. Every piece of code we write is (hopefully) carefully reviewed by our teammates before becoming part of our systems. It's an important part of the development process, and it requires significant time and effort.

While a great review experience will promote interesting discussions, ensure consistency in the codebase, and potentially catch bugs and implementation oversights, a poor review might lead to nasty bugs and unhappy developers. Still, sometimes it's hard to find the motivation to thoroughly review a pull request, and eventually it just doesn't seem to be worth it given the time you'll need to spend and how hard it usually is to properly review those huge PRs that pop up every now and then.

In this talk you'll learn strategies and guidelines that will help improve the efficiency of your team's code reviews. We'll talk about work in progress PRs, commit by commit reviews, emoji driven comments and more. You'll listen to great (and scary) tales of code reviews experiences, and lots of tips and tricks when it comes to preparing the perfect pull request for your peers.
FWP-0664.title: The Art of Code Reviews

FZF-4536.description:
Android est l'OS mobile le plus r√©pandu au monde. C'est √©galement un OS tr√®s ouvert disposant de stores applicatifs. De plus, il est utilis√© pour plusieurs cas d'usage n√©cessitant une forte s√©curit√©: Banque / DRM /  Sant√© / Donn√©es personnelles.

Voyons ensemble comment Android garanti le plus haut niveau de s√©curit√© pour son OS.
FZF-4536.title: La s√©curit√© de l'os Android

FZH-4805.description: 65% of developers starting #Kotlin project choose RxJava 2 as a background work tool. But are you sure the choice is justified? Kotlin coroutines can be a powerful replacement for RxJava in an Android project. In this talk, we are going to compare the approaches, consider their pros and cons, and see when coroutines are more convenient, and when you are doomed without Rx. We will also see how unit testing differs between two approaches and how they can live together in a project.
FZH-4805.title: Forget RxJava: Kotlin Coroutines are all you need

FZK-9864.description:
When you look around among your developer friends and colleagues you‚Äôll probably find that most of them use a computer running Windows or macOS. Sometimes that‚Äôs personal choice, in other cases employers or clients dictate which platform one would have to use. Every year around Christmas time there are articles with titles similar to ‚ÄúWhy 20xx will be the year of the Linux desktop‚Äù, but has it ever really been *that* year?

In 2018, I made the jump from using macOS as my main platform to Linux and since then, people don‚Äôt stop to ask me how it went, what I did, what problems I ran into and why *they* could probably never make such a platform transition. The truth is: they - and you - probably could do it just fine as well.

In this talk, I‚Äôll talk about and explain the pros and cons of my move to Linux. Starting from hardware and distributions choices to very Android-specific development challenges. Along the way I‚Äôll explain the audience some of the underlying Linux concepts and show tools to match what they might be used to from Mac or Windows. After this talk, people will hopefully be more confident when it comes to leaving the mainstream operating systems macOS and Windows.
FZK-9864.title: The trials and tribulations of moving to Linux as a (mobile) developer

GAO-2888.description:
In this talk, you will learn about best practices to gather insights,  mixed with real life experiences and anecdotes. Understand why people are doing certain tasks, not only what they are doing. 
Basically, improve your apps, by asking the right questions.

No budget for user research? Learn what you can do under the radar to understand the user behaviour better. You will get examples on how it can be done, regardless if you are a bigger company, or an indie developer!
GAO-2888.title: The difference between what and why.

GBA-2488.description:
GraphQL is not new, and REST is still around. Is it already time to switch? What tools can we rely on, as of today? Is the framework ready and suitable for everyone around?
At The New York Times, we invested heavily on this technology, so much that we actually created a whole new feature around it. Join us to discover the inner depths of GraphQL, how it works and how it can be integrated within a few days. Explore how you can make sure about what you write and test it out. And when it's time to optimize, maybe we can help it!
GBA-2488.title: GraphQL in real life

GJC-5311.description:
Nous allons d√©couvrir les bases du langage Kotlin.
En quelques mots, ce langage moderne permet de coder des applications tournant dans l'environnement Java, Android ou directement en natif. En plus de cela, il int√®gre tellement de sucres syntaxiques et de concepts absents en Java qu'il donne un coup de vieux √† ce dernier !.
Vous allez voir, c'est un langage trop top qui vous fera oublier le Java ;).
GJC-5311.title: D√©couverte de Kotlin en live Coding

GJI-2631.description: All those fancy keywords might make the content of this talk sound complex and advanced. Many concepts around AI and ML can be overwhelming or imply a time consuming steep learning curve. Fear not, both Flutter and Firebase come in our rescue. In this talk, we'll review basic concepts of Machine Learning(for fun and profit), understand availability and capabilities of APIs provided by ML Kit(look ma, -almost-no math) and how to implement features like face recognition and image labeling in our apps in no time(although time is a construct). Our agenda will include an overview of  the tools of choice (Flutter and ML Kit), what's available in the cross-platform world of Flutter and ML, working with on-device and cloud APIs, what could be the next steps after mastering the basics and understanding the implementation through a sample app.
GJI-2631.title: Smartly smartest apps with cross-platform Machine Learning (using Flutter and ML Kit)

GMB-7169.description:
On vous demande de coder une *vue custom* ? Peur de l'inconnu, le mot canevas fait peur √† entendre, n'ayez crainte, c'est beaucoup beaucoup plus compliqu√© sur papier que √ßa ne l'est dans le code !

Nous apprendrons ensemble : 
- comment utiliser les classes Canvas et Paint
- comment dessiner des vues simples : Rectangles, Ronds
- comment dessiner des vues un peu plus complexes : RoundRect, Triangles
- comment animer notre vue custom
GMB-7169.title: S‚Äôil te plait, dessine moi une vue

GMY-6673.description:
Have ever opened your designer‚Äôs mockup only to throw your hands up in despair?

You might have seen animations in your favourite app and wondered how many hours they took to create. Now, thanks to the introduction of MotionLayout, delighting our users with elegant and meaningful motion has never been easier.

The preview release of the MotionLayout library was one of the most exciting announcements of Google I/O 2018. 1 year later it has matured into an incredibly powerful and intuitive tool for creating user driven animations. This talk introduces MotionLayout, explains the underlying mathematical theory used to create it.

The talk will step through the main features of the library, including Motion Scenes, Custom Attributes, Image Filters, Keyframes and more. We will discuss how you can harness MotionLayout to improve UI maintainability, reduce duplication of XML layout and give greater power and flexibility to craft meaningful UI animations and interactions.

Come along to this session to learn how you can use ConstraintLayout 2.0 and MotionLayout to craft complex and beautiful UI interactions with ease.
GMY-6673.title: Notions about Motions

GNU-8865.description:
Most of us have been through the moves: you join a new company, you really like their product and are excited about working there. On your first few days, you start getting familiar with the codebase, and... that's precisely when you discover the skeletons. From old and no-longer-maintained dependencies, no architecture consistency, rogue and half-baked experimental technologies, to zero documentation and ‚Äî obviously ‚Äî no trace of any tests. Sounds familiar? 

In this talk, you will learn how to effectively deal with old codebases while trying to modernize them and bring them up to 2019 quality standards. This will include not only tips, tricks and best practices, but practical guidance on where to start, what to touch (and what to postpone) and how to envision a brighter future.

Tears were shed, blood was drawn, rage was unleashed. Let me save you some of it.
GNU-8865.title: Skeletons in the closet ‚Äî Effective legacy management

GPO-8338.description:
Il existe d√©sormais de multiples frameworks de test, √† l‚Äôimage de mockk ou mockito-kotlin, permettant d‚Äôexploiter au mieux les sp√©cificit√©s du langage Kotlin pour √©crire des tests de fa√ßon toujours plus ais√©e et expressive.
Dans cette pr√©sentation je vous donnerai les principales fonctionnalit√©s, avantages, et inconv√©nients de plusieurs de ces frameworks. Si vous √™tes √† la recherche du nouveau framework de test de vos r√™ves ou alors √† l‚Äô√©coute de best practices li√©es aux tests en Kotlin, ce talk est fait pour vous.
GPO-8338.title: State of the art Kotlin unit testing

HDV-6804.description:
Oui, on le sait : vous en avez assez des talks d'architecture mobile. On vous comprend, vous avez d√ª en voir des tonnes : utiles, superflus, simples, alambiqu√©s, certains m√™me impronon√ßables et l√† vous n‚Äôen pouvez plus.

Mais donnez-nous une chance : cette fois-ci nous voulons vous pr√©senter une architecture que nous appr√©cions v√©ritablement : simple, robuste, facilement testable et tirant profit des langages modernes comme Kotlin et Swift - Model-View-Intention. Inspir√©e de Redux, mais adapt√©e aux applications mobiles, MVI se sert d'immutabilit√©, flux de donn√©es unidirectionnel et binding pour faciliter d√©bogage et testing et am√©liorer donc votre productivit√©. Applicable √† Android et iOS, elle permet aussi de simplifier les √©changes entre les √©quipes de d√©veloppeurs d'applications mobiles natives.

Nous vous pr√©senterons les √©l√©ments cl√©s de l'architecture, sa mise en place, ainsi que l'impl√©mentation des cas d'usage les plus communs, issus d'applications que nous avons r√©ellement d√©velopp√©es.
HDV-6804.title: MVI : une architecture robuste et moderne

HJM-2968.description:
A bunch of Google Developers Experts will come on stage, discovering a few applications in live, they will provide feedback and advices to the developers.
Propose your application for the review by sending the Play Store link or the APK to contact@androidmakers.fr
HJM-2968.title: App Clinic

HJU-0919.description:
Remote work is becoming more and more popular, but how do you build and maintain effective teams that are spread throughout space and time?

Engaged, effective remote teams don't happen by accident. They require buy-in, trust, communication and empathy. Thankfully, there are a variety of strategies & tools that help make a remote team effective and enjoyable.

In this talk we'll explore:

- common concerns & how to handle them
- effective communication strategies
- how to handle different timezones
- tools to make remote workflows nice and smooth
- how to keep your team engaged and productive
HJU-0919.title: Working Effectively Across Space-Time

HND-9795.description:
Unleash your creativity while actively listening to talks! Sketchnoting is the art of using visuals to record and share ideas. Come to learn about taking notes, and how to make beautiful sketches with the help of lettering techniques.

Taking notes in a visual way, while actively listening to talks, is an excellent way to remember the most important ideas and going back to them in the future. You can also use sketchnoting to share ideas at work or to organize your day.

You will learn sketchnoting techniques by the hand of two established ‚Äúsketchnoters‚Äù while making your first sketch! And as well, you will learn the basics of lettering, the art of writing beautiful captions. The two instructors will be also sketchnoting with you, sharing their process live!

Everyone can get started with sketchnoting, you only need pen and paper!
HND-9795.title: Sketchnoting & Lettering Workshop

HRV-8541.description:
With great power comes great responsibilities. In today‚Äôs world, developers definitely have a lot of power in their hands, shaping the apps we use every day on our phones and computers. More than ever developers need to know about the consequences of what they build, and help shape the way apps will be built tomorrow.

Most talks at conferences helps you become better developers technically, revealing the best practices, tips and tricks, or new libraries and framework to write better code, this talk will focus on making you becoming a more ethical developer.
HRV-8541.title: Being an Ethical Developer

HWF-0101.description:
Well, this was coming, wasn‚Äôt it? The time of the year when Google introduces developer features through it‚Äôs I/O with the primary emphasis on better code practice and reduced development burden to implement this best practice. One such feature is the Navigation Controller of the Android Architecture Components.

What if you were given a Storyboard which has a blueprint of the application‚Äôs logical flow much like in iOS? You don't have to worry about doing fragment transactions manually, follow the best practice for deep linking, maintain a testable code base, manage argument passing straight from the layout editor and the most important point of 'em all, emphasis is high on single activity-multiple fragment codebase. Amazed? Well, join me as I take you through the Navigation Controller of Architectural Components! üòÉ
HWF-0101.title: Navigation Controller - An Android Storyboard?

HWQ-8384.description:
Avec le turnover que connaissent actuellement nos soci√©t√©s d'information, on voit souvent passer du monde sur une m√™me appli.
Or chaque dev semble avoir son architecture pr√©f√©r√©e, ses "bonnes pratiques", et chaque nouvel arrivant tentera soit de refaire l'archi qu'il conna√Æt de sa derni√®re exp√©rience, soit de s'int√©grer √† cette archi qu'il ne conna√Æt pas forc√©ment... et l√† c'est le drame. 

Et si on prenait quelques minutes pour revoir ensemble tous ces buzzwords, les connecter, se poser, comprendre les intentions derri√®re chaque pattern, r√©fl√©chir aux pour, aux contres et se munir pour la prochaine mission.
Et on en profitera aussi pour faire une petite incursion vers ce que nous propose Android en 2019 pour impl√©menter tous ces beaux patterns.
HWQ-8384.title: MVC, MVP, MVVM, VIPER, Clean-Archi, DDD, TDD, BDD ... Help j'y comprends rien !

HXB-5769.description: Que l‚Äôon d√©veloppe une application pour smartphones ou pour un IoT, la connectivit√© est un √©l√©ment cl√©. Id√©alement, on voudrait √† la fois minimiser la latence et la consommation d‚Äô√©nergie. Concr√®tement, c‚Äôest difficilement faisable. En balayant tout un tas de technos, du WiFi √† LTE-M, en passant par la 2,3,4,5G, nous verrons les m√©canismes qui sont mis en place pour pr√©server l‚Äôautonomie d‚Äôun appareil et qui in√©vitablement induisent de la latence.
HXB-5769.title: Energie, latence: je t'aime, moi non plus

HZY-9508.description:
Many teams are designed so that engineers can take an abstract view of the customer and focus on implementation. But when the customers are other engineers, that entire dynamic is thrown on it's head.

In this talk, Ty will walk you through the best practices of building great products for developers, from team processes to the technical delivery.

Topics covered will include: Building customer personas and product strategies, Developer Experience research and analytics, customer empathy and support structures, API Design and usability, testing, code distribution, and creating great documentation.
HZY-9508.title: Building for Developers

ICP-5281.description:
Ready to start building the Internet of Things, but aren‚Äôt sure where to start?

Android Things makes this easier by enabling you to leverage your existing knowledge, tools, and services to build smart, connected devices. However, the process can seem a bit daunting at first.

In this talk, you'll learn step by step how to build a connected smart display for comic book collectibles as we walk through the following questions:

- what hardware/software is needed to get started with Android Things?
- how to train a custom TensorFlow Lite model?
- how to use ML Kit for Firebase to distribute and update your model on edge devices?
- how to consume your model on your Android Things hardware?
- how to use the model to load & display data from Firebase depending on what it sees?
ICP-5281.title: Impractically Practical IoT

IJA-6666.description:
In this modern day we often take things for granted. From the apps we use, the things we buy to the clothes we wear - it's easy to get wrapped up in our consumption and forget how easy it is for us to interact with these things. Now imagine if there was a change of circumstance - would you still be able to interact with the device that you're reading this on? How would your experience have been getting to the location that you're currently at, or brew that coffee you made this morning?

Without being in these positions ourselves, it can be too easy to make things that might work well for us, but not necessarily be usable by those who are not in the same position. In this talk I want to explore this mindset so that we can think outside of our comfort zone, in the hope that more people can be enabled to explore the things that we experience.
IJA-6666.title: Inclusive Craft

INJ-1475.description:
When you transition from a Java-heavy codebase to a Kotlin one, you might think you are ‚Äúdoing Kotlin right‚Äù by using language features like extension functions, data classes, smart casting and so forth. Then slowly, the PR comments creep in about making your Kotlin code more ‚ÄúKotlin-ey‚Äù and you enter the debates of ‚Äúwho wrote this better?‚Äù You begin to wonder, is the ‚ÄúKotlin way‚Äù of doing things always better than the ‚ÄúJava way‚Äù? 

In this talk, we will learn how we can improve our Kotlin code to be more idiomatic by going beyond the basics with Single expression functions, Delegated properties and Lazy, De-structuring declarations, Operator overloading, Sequences, Type aliases, Inline classes and more, while leveraging our existing knowledge of Java.
 
With the help of practical examples straight from the Blinkist codebase, we will go over guiding principles or a ¬†‚Äúcheatsheet‚Äù to have in mind when working with Kotlin - one that I wish I had early on.   We will also learn how to apply the Kotlin Style Guide and use static analysis tools to help us write clean, consistent and idiomatic code, thus keeping our teams happy and productive.
INJ-1475.title: The Kotlin Cheatsheet: Getting to Idiomatic Kotlin

IRT-4165.description:
In the current times, Mobile application development is a way different and far advanced than what it used to be earlier. Things have changed considerably and keeping up to date with them is now a necessity than just some acquirable knowledge. So, replacing the same mobile app development with multiple codebases targeting multiple platforms with an SSCB (Single Solid CodeBase).

Flutter is a new invention from Google for building more high-performance, rich-UI apps for both Android & iOS platforms from a single codebase. Developers usually called flutter as a UI Toolkit, but technically it's a mobile app SDK. It will give the wings to the developers to expand their barriers of thinking the more creative design and build mobile applications in a fast virt mode. Lots of advantages for the developers and finally "No Mobile development experience is required to get started" for newbies.

By the end of the session, you will be all set to know how to start developing the apps using Flutter in a practical approach.
IRT-4165.title: Fast and Furious with Flutter

ITM-7129.description:
L‚Äôapplication mobile cr√©√©e, Marty et Doc se disent qu‚Äôils ne leur manquent qu‚Äôune chose :  
  
‚Äì _Tu sais coder un backend, Marty ?_  
‚Äì _Non, Doc, vous savez tr√®s bien que je d√©veloppe juste des applications front !_  
  
Le stress monte d‚Äôun cran :  
  
‚Äì _Nom de Zeus, tu ne sais pas que tu peux r√©tablir le continum espace-temps en utilisant tes connaissances en Kotlin pour du back ?_  
‚Äì _H√©, attendez un peu, Doc. Est-ce que j‚Äôai bien entendu ? Je pourrais d√©ployer n‚Äôimporte quelle appli rapidement ?_  
‚Äì _Faut voir grand dans la vie, Marty ! **Avec Spark, KMongo, Heroku et mLab, cr√©er un backend en Kotlin est devenu simple.**_  
  
Par√©s, ils montent dans la DeLorean, allument le contact et appuient sur l‚Äôacc√©l√©rateur :  
  
‚Äì _Nom de Zeus !!! On y est, Marty ! Tu es pr√™t √† avoir un backend en Kotlin, ou tu es trop poule mouill√©e pour le d√©couvrir ?_  
‚Äì _Personne ne me tra√Æte de poule mouill√©e !_
ITM-7129.title: Kotlin: back your future

IVS-2334.description:
A core use-case for Facebook for Android is scrolling through a feed of autoplaying videos. We've needed to have a deep understanding of video playback to optimize performance in our apps.

In this talk, we‚Äôll examine the details behind video playback on Android. We‚Äôll look at the actors that play a role in delivering decoded video pixels to the screen. We‚Äôll go beyond the high-level MediaPlayer / ExoPlayer components and examine what's happening in the system. Understanding how video playback works under the hood can help you figure out how to get the best performance for your applications.

We‚Äôll cover the details behind fundamental graphics components used by video rendering: e.g. SurfaceView, TextureView, SurfaceTexture, etc. These components also enable more complex media rendering such as 360 videos, 3D scenes, and AR experiences.

We hope to leave you empowered to look deeper into the Android system beyond the high-level Android framework components and expand your knowledge and expertise.
IVS-2334.title: Rendering Video: A Detailed Look at Video Playback on Android

JEH-1710.description:
You can run Android on a wide range of devices, not just phones and tablets. Building Android from scratch is fun and a great way to learn about the lower levels of the operating system. Imagine - here is a chance to create ANY Android configuration you want.

In this presentation, I will show you how to take a Raspberry Pi 3 and build Android completely from scratch, using source code from the AOSP (Android Open Source Project). We will need a few things to make this work
A Linux kernel that has been configured with the options that Android expects
OpenGL ES graphics drivers
HAL layers for graphics and networking, amongst other things

he final hurdle is understanding the way that the RPi boots and adapting it to boot Android. Then, at last, we get to the point where we can write the images to a microSD card and boot up the RPi. One last problem: the Raspberry Pi 3 doesn‚Äôt have a USB OTG port, so we can‚Äôt use ADB in the normal way. No problem, we can use ADB over Ethernet instead.

This presentation focuses on the Raspberry Pi, but in a similar way you can port Android to many other devices. If it can run Linux, there is a good chance it can run Android.
JEH-1710.title: Building Android for the Raspberry Pi

JFQ-0548.description:
Kotlin is a great language. But we‚Äôve all met situations where a certain feature was missing, and we wished were part of the it.

Since programs are basically functions, and functions are first-class citizen in Kotlin, it‚Äôs possible to implement ‚Äúpseudo-keywords‚Äù at a short cost and to great value.

There are many useful use-cases for this trick. For instance, you can implement a very transparent caching mechanism , nicely compose asynchronous functions, add a debouncing layer, and many other use cases.

In this talk you'll learn about how this techniques works, along with examples that leverage it to solve standard problems an app may encounter. After that, you'll be all set to apply it to your own apps! 
‚Äã
JFQ-0548.title: Implementing pseudo-keywords through functional programing ‚Äã

JFX-3997.description:
From code to release, the android team at Buffer has always had a manual process in place. Whilst all of the tasks that make up the development lifecycle are not individually trivial, added together these can add a lot of cognitive lode and knowledge silo to our process.

This year at Buffer we've been slowly adding automated steps to our workflow, moving us towards a truly automated Continuos Delivery workflow. From code review to scheduled releases, in this talk I want to share with you both why and how we've automated our entire workflow so that you can too.
JFX-3997.title: From Review to Release: Automate everything!

JHA-1941.description: Flutter just turned 1.0 so it should be ready for prime time but how do we go about creating an flutter app lets find this out by creating an Star wars movie app on top of the the MovieDB api and running that on both Android and IOS.
JHA-1941.title: Dart: I'm your Flutter

JHX-2375.description:
As your codebase grows, it can become increasingly difficult to manage and test it. Development is slowed down and the code quality diminishes. It's time to modularize.

How will modules affect the development process and the architecture? How will the build time be impacted? What considerations should you take into account when designing the module hierarchy? I'll try to answer all these questions during this presentation, while going over our own experience of breaking an Android project into Gradle modules.
JHX-2375.title: Modularize an Android Project

JJK-6338.description:
One of the stated goals of Android Architecture Components is to make it easier for developers to manage the lifecycle of application components. However, when looking at the full picture of combining configuration changes and background memory constraints with static and dynamic state, the basic examples provided in the documentation begin to show their limitations. A more in-depth exploration is needed.

We'll look at how to combine bundles and view models to fully persist the state of the application during its lifecycle. Using coroutines for concurrency, we'll see how dynamic state restoration can be achieved.

Going over increasingly complex examples of state restoration constraints, we'll see how our implementation of state restoration grows and evolves.
JJK-6338.title: State Restoration - The full Picture (With Coroutines)

JOO-6049.description:
Koin (https://insert-koin.io) is a pragmatic dependency injection framework for Kotlin/Android developers. Let's see how it will make your life easier thanks to the power of Kotlin language: from basics to the setup of Android architecture's components, without forgetting the testing part...  And of course, how to migrate your "old" Dagger project. 

At the menu also, the presentation of the new 2.0 release and some advanced APIs!
JOO-6049.title: Dependency injection from zero to hero with Koin

JSD-5161.description: Vector assets are lightweight and sharp on every screen size, but working with them can be complicated. Android doesn‚Äôt directly support SVG, potentially leading to conversion and ownership issues. This talk will cover what designers and developers need to know to work together to create static and animated vector assets. We‚Äôll cover the capabilities of Android‚Äôs vector formats, how they influence producing assets in graphics packages (with a focus on Sketch) and how to efficiently export them. We'll also look at tooling and workflows that allow designers and devs to collaborate on creating vector animations.
JSD-5161.title: Vector Workflows

JSX-0552.description: It's the graal of every developer, finding the perfect language to help them tule on all platforms. Many tried but most failed. Is Kotlin the final answer? Come see my talk and I'll show you how versatile, flexible and easy to use Kotlin on your favorite platform and beyond!
JSX-0552.title: Kotlin: one language to rule them all

JYW-2224.description:
L‚Äôisolation de fragments de codes au sein d‚Äôune biblioth√®que est une t√¢che qui pouvait √™tre faite ais√©ment en quelques lignes de script gradle. Cependant, afin de pouvoir √™tre utilis√©e ais√©ment par d‚Äôautres d√©veloppeurs, son design, son impl√©mentation et sa distribution doivent ob√©ir √† certaines r√®gles. Dans le cas contraire, son int√©gration deviendra p√©nible et conduira √† une perte de temps et d'√©nergie pour les d√©veloppeurs souhaitant l‚Äôutiliser.

Dans cette pr√©sentation, je vous donnerai quelques conseils pour √©viter de tomber dans les pi√®ges classiques d‚Äôun d√©veloppement de biblioth√®que. Cela vous conduira √† maximiser la ‚Äúdeveloper experience‚Äù, et donc atteindre une adoption plus importante de votre biblioth√®que ; mais aussi r√©duire les retours et les demandes d‚Äôajustement que vous feront au fur et √† mesure les personnes qui l‚Äôutilisent.
JYW-2224.title: Best practices de d√©veloppement d‚Äôune biblioth√®que pour Android

KBD-0185.description:
Bringing Junior developers into your team can be a challenge, but it can also be rewarding. Mentoring can benefit both sides: It can help juniors with the most difficult moment in their career, and it can help seniors become better professionals. Come and learn how juniors and seniors can support each other and grow together.

You can benefit from this talk no matter what‚Äôs your level of expertise. As a junior, you will learn that you are not alone, that you can stop the impostors syndrome, and to be a better apprentice. As a senior, you will learn the benefits of being a good mentor, and how to become one. I will share my experience as a developer who is working on growing up in the career ladder.
KBD-0185.title: Supporting Each Other: Growth for Juniors and Seniors

KDY-8005.description:
An exploratory talk that showcases how Android can deliver a beautiful experience to the user using material design principles and various framework APIs like gestures and spans. This talk walks the user through a collection of concrete examples of custom UI components and their implementations in my gesture driven Reddit app, Dank.


1. Recreating Google Inbox‚Äôs UI for expandable descendant navigation
2. Using nested scrolling APIs for building a comment sheet
3. Building collapsible comments in RecyclerView by leveraging elevation APIs
4. Designing a gesture for flick dismissing images
5. Building a text editor that renders Markdown in real-time

Dank is open source and can be found on Github: github.com/saket/dank
KDY-8005.title: Behind the scenes of building a gesture driven Reddit app

KFU-1114.description:
En plus des Activity, Broadcast et Service, nous avons tous appris que l'une des briques de base du framework Android est le ContentProvider. Le premier usage de cette classe et de permettre de fournir et d'exposer des donn√©es √† d'autres applications de mani√®re s√©curis√©e.

Aujourd'hui, cette classe est quelque peu d√©laiss√©e et reste obscure pour un grand nombre d'entre nous.

Cette pr√©sentation va montrer qu'en d√©poussi√©rant le concept, il est tout √† fait possible d'utiliser les ContentProvider - ici appel√©s InitProvider - afin d'initialiser des SDK tiers ou d'autres modules sans passer par l'habituelle classe Application.

Cette mani√®re originale d'initialisation permet de de cloisonner les SDK tiers et de simplifier grandement la lecture et la maintenance du code
Elle permet aussi aux √©diteurs de SDK de donner aux int√©grateurs une fa√ßon simple et automatique d'initialiser leur solution (√† l'instar de ce qui se fait pour Firebase).

Cette courte pr√©sentation permettra de montrer plusieurs exemples de SDK connus initialis√©s de cette mani√®re, et a pour but d'inciter la communaut√© √† travailler de cette fa√ßon qui nous semble beaucoup plus industrielle.
KFU-1114.title: Initialisez votre application √† l'aide d'InitProvider !

KKO-2668.description:
Android development has evolved dramatically these past years thanks to RxJava, LiveData and navigation components. Have you completely embraced all these new technologies yet? Should you even? What are the benefits? Best practices? Pitfalls? How on earth should you even architect an app in 2019?

This talk will show you how to architect a modern Android app. You'll learn how streams, architecture components, and LiveData can dramatically simplify app development. And we'll do all of that by converting an existing application to RxJava and LiveData! So you immediately learn how these principles can help you solve real-life problems.

Some of the topics include:
- handling orientation/lifecycle changes with LiveData
- using navigation components
- subscribing and doing operations with streams
- swapping between Threads
- using RxBinding to debounce clicks
- simultaneously communicate with multiple backends
- ...
KKO-2668.title: Modern reactive Android development by example

KOV-9403.description: Animations bring your app to life but often we write them as pre-canned sequences that once started can‚Äôt be interrupted or redirected. Modern Android apps are reactive to state changes‚Ä¶ your animations should be as well. This talk looks at techniques for writing animations that work like state machines, that can be interrupted or retargeted while running. We‚Äôll look at ways to architect your animations to achieve this, and libraries and classes that we can utilize.
KOV-9403.title: Motional Intelligence: Build smarter animations

KOZ-5415.description: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.
KOZ-5415.title: Talk Moyen

KQI-6087.description:
It is amazing what we do - we never settle, we always try to test new things and improve the ones on which we work daily; whether it‚Äôs a new library, an architecture pattern or in this particular case a new language: Kotlin! 

However those things have different impacts on our projects - using a new library has a different risk than adopting a new language and this is where things get complicated.

For the past years I‚Äôve been trying to evangelise - wololooo - [read this with Age Of Empires priests voice] the people at my company and community into gradually start using Kotlin. 

It's never easy. First, not everyone shares the same enthusiasm in learning something new and secondly making the shift of leaving a language which they know and are familiar with to a new one requires time (both for companies and for people).

Fast forward to the present and currently we have Kotlin code in production, a team thrilled with learning new things and managers glad that all deadlines have been successfully accomplished.

I‚Äôm going to share all the steps made since I first started to push Kotlin until we have an application in production powered by it. Hopefully, without making you fall asleep.
KQI-6087.title: Kotlin my way in

KRF-2130.description:
The life of a programmer is all about making decisions. As an Android developer, you have probably taken a lot of choices that have impacted every project you've ever worked on. Should I spend a bit more time defining a testable and robust architecture? Should I switch to Kotlin, or stick to Java? Should I reuse this open source library or create my own solution? Should I modularize my project? And it goes on...

The truth is that most of those questions don't have binary answers. As you would expect, the answer for most of them could easily be "it depends". During this talk, you'll hear a lot of scenarios, some of which you have maybe faced before. We'll see that it's not only about our perspective as developers, there's much more to consider. The goal of the talk is for you identify the tradeoffs between each alternative, and to provide guidelines that help you take the most appropriate decision for your own needs.
KRF-2130.title: Decision making as an Android developer - it's not just about us

KRP-2686.description:
As Deezer team expanded over the last years, making changes and maintaining design in the app became a major concern:  
 - How to keep the different screens of the app consistent and let the design evolve?  
 - How to ensure consistency across platforms / applications?  
 - How to fill knowledge gaps between designers and developers?  

### Atomic Design
To tackle these issues, we decided to build a strong design system. Brad Frost developed a methodology called [Atomic Design](http://atomicdesign.bradfrost.com/)  to create and maintain robust design systems, defining UI components in a bottom up organized hierarchy: from the tinier bricks (atoms and molecules) to the bigger ones (organisms). We took inspiration from it with our own metaphor: Lego bricks.

### UIKit: an Android implementation of our design system
To build our design system, we established with designers a UIKit, a pattern library (implemented as an android library) defining every UI component of the app. During the presentation, we will dive in the UIKit to see how:  
 - brick components are defined  
 - versioning and breaking changes are managed  
 - the UIKit is progressively integrated in the app
KRP-2686.title: Let your design evolve, adopt a UIKit

KSG-3809.description:
Sharing code between platforms is a powerful technique, but it may be hard to accomplish without rich APIs that we have in Android, JVM, or iOS platforms. Kotlin Multiplatform libraries can be used to fix that, bringing rich APIs directly in the common Kotlin code. 

What an exciting frontier!
