In this talk we'll go over the creation of a Kotlin Multiplatform library. You'll learn how modules for each platform work, decide what parts of the code makes sense to share and what doesn't. All based in the experiences gathered after creating a library at Mixtiles used to fetch images from different cloud providers.
KSG-3809.title: Building a library for Android and iOS using Kotlin Multiplatform

KSY-5944.description:
One big struggle for many Android developers is to be dealing with animations. The whole Android framework doesn't give really good support for it and ofter it does not look as smooth as planned.

Luckily, Google has been working in improving the support for it. Besides the already existing tools, such as Property Animation framework, Layout transitions or Animated Vector Drawables, Google also brought in the ConstraintLayout 2.0, the new MotionLayout.

With this layout, animations are made easy and intuitive. In this talk, we will be able to take a brief look at: 
1. Basic animation transitions based on Constraints
2. Image transitions
3. How to use keyframes
and
4. How to take advantage of MotionLayout inside the existing layouts
KSY-5944.title: MotionLayout: Animation made easy

KVN-2060.description: The promise of cross-platform frameworks looks great on paper, and some of them do a pretty good job delivering actual results. But with inherent differences between platforms, is "build once, run anywhere" even worth pursuing? Learn how you can share parts of your app between mobile platforms (and even the web!) without compromising quality, and delivering a best in class Android experience. During this talk I'll explain some ideas on how to structure not only your code, but also your teams, I'll show how to implement your own Kotlin MP libraries and showcase a few ones that you can use out-of-the-box.
KVN-2060.title: Kotlin Multiplatform: code sharing without compromise

KXA-3088.description: D√©couvrons ensemble, et en live coding, les nouveaut√©s de Kotlin 1.3 dont les inline classes, les contrats, la s√©rialisation, la stabilisation des coroutines et autres nouveaut√©s succulentes.
KXA-3088.title: Les nouveaut√©s de Kotlin 1.3 en Live Coding

KZX-0989.description: The Android community has been steadily growing the past couple of years. Communication channels, specialized events, global conferences and speakers traveling around the world have helped to blurry the borders. As our community aims for maturity we also need to keep working on bind together the several regions where Android devs are active. Sharing, linking and exchanging from ideas to code, tweets, talks, and slack channels, in many ways, collaboration sparks amazing results and we've been experiencing this in our community. In this talk, we'll share my experience as speaker, how the Latin american android community has developed the past couple of years, how it has integrated with the global community and how everyone can strength the connections with the global community through inclusion, mentorship and empathy.
KZX-0989.title: Connecting the global Android community with Latin America

LCL-4887.description:
One way to describe what majority of Android apps do is saying that they just showing data
Yet most of the patterns out there don‚Äôt talk about the data at all, In this talk, you will understand why you must have a data layer and  you will see a suggested way to add such with Kotlin coroutine or RxJava
LCL-4887.title: Respect Your App's Data‚Ää-‚ÄäAdd Data Layer

LDA-5970.description:
There are many options on Android for deferrable background work. During this workshop you will learn about WorkManager, a compatible, flexible and simple library for deferrable background work.
WorkManager is the recommended solution for scheduling and executing deferrable background work in Android.
LDA-5970.title: Background Work with WorkManager

LDK-3602.description:
Mobile application performance is very important metric it influences user's experience.
In that talk I'd like share experience about mobile application performance analytics, describe techniques to implement performance monitoring in mobile products. 
I'll answer the question how improve performance and increase user's engagement.
LDK-3602.title: Performance analytics path of samurai

LHE-4033.description:
Binding xml in an Activity, a Fragment or a View, and using MVW (Model View _Whatever_) is not the only way to make UIs on Android. More generally: **A way that works is rarely the only that can.**

When I got started using Kotlin back in 2016, I tried Anko layouts, a library to use the Android Java APIs for Views in a nicer way thanks to Kotlin abilities. Short story, I got back to xml when ConstraintLayout was released, which Anko didn't support back then.

Then, after thinking about it and finding inspiration, I tried to make an Anko alternative that would be lighter and more flexible. This succeeded and became [Splitties Views DSL](https://github.com/LouisCAD/Splitties), but I didn't stop there.

After completely dropping xml layouts for over a year, I started to envision new ways to make my UIs, leveraging `interface`s that would be contracts that my UI classes would implement.
This new approach is giving me a flexibility that I like to have: Testing different UI designs is now very easy, and **leveraging coroutines, the code reads like a simple bullet list**, rather than like a small dictionary.

In this talk, I'll focus on that use case centric way of designing UIs.
LHE-4033.title: UI contracts on Android with Kotlin, coroutines and Splitties

LHZ-1723.description:
Abstract
Different things in Android have never been easy to deal with since ages.

Fragments lifecyle, navigation & multiple back stacks, how to handle and persist data in case of activity destroyed or in case of configuration change, are only a small set of those things, let's focus togheter and see how to solve this issues in the 'old manner' and using new suggested approach Jetpack + AAC.

I will explore different solutions how to approach to the bottom navigation with multiple back stack issue using Fragment plus FragmentManager (with and without the usage of the internal stack), and we'll present great improvements we have since the release of Navigation component and the powerful combo "JetPack + AAC" expecially in terms of common problems like 'screen rotation', 'activity destroyed', 'state persistent'.
LHZ-1723.title: Bottom navigation into 2019

LNH-0175.description:
Wind back one year ago:
- releasing took us 10 weeks
- our app was plagued by regression
- developers felt completely detached from our users

Clearly our traditional strategy of heavily testing each release (up-front quality) wasn't working. So we decided to flip things around: why not try to reduce the cost of errors instead? Hence we decided to move our Philips Hue Android app to continuous deployment.

In this talk you will learn that if releasing is painful, you should actually release even more often. Step by step I'll explain how we moved the Philips Hue Android app to continuous deployment, what our current release process/CI looks like, what changes we made to our overall testing approach, how we empowered developers and testers, and how we made our release process completely painless.
LNH-0175.title: Journey to painless releases: Continuous delivery for Philips Hue Android

LQF-6083.description:
We Android developers love desert. We love pie. We can't eat up a whole pie, but we can eat as many slices as we want.
Android has a new API called Slices which is part of the AndroidX libraries. I'll show you how you can use it to serve slices of your app to any other apps like Google Search or Assistant but also any other app and in any Android desert you love.
LQF-6083.title: Slices up your app!

LSR-7598.description:
Dependency injection libraries have become a staple in Android development and are the way to go nowadays when it comes to your application's infrastructure.

We've all heard of Dagger2 as a solution, but its learning curve is steep. Are there other libraries that can aid us?

In this lecture, you will learn about other dependency injection libraries and how they compare to Dagger2.
There is no right or wrong way. Therefore, by the end of the lecture, you will be confident in the library of your choice for your app's dependency injection needs!
LSR-7598.title: Dagger or Kodein? Let's flip a Koin!

LWJ-6534.description: This talk will focus on some of the more advances features built on top of LeakCanary as well as new features coming up: leak detection in tests, much smarter leaktraces as well as improved UI, memory leak detection in production, etc.
LWJ-6534.title: LeakCanary.next

LYT-4660.description:
Architecture is the foundation of an app yet it remains overlooked and misunderstood. One of the reasons is, we can still create great functional apps without having a proper architecture. The price we pay for bad architecture usually comes at a later stage when a change is required in the app.

One doesn't need to be a Software Architect to develop an app with a decent architecture. Google, for this reason, introduced Architecture components so that even beginners may focus on the architecture of the app. 

Let's learn how we can develop maintainable apps using Clean Architecture.
LYT-4660.title: Developing Clean Architecture apps

MAW-7262.description: In this workshop we‚Äôll be looking at coroutines - Kotlin‚Äôs way of handling asynchronous programming. We‚Äôll see what they are, how they work, how to call tasks written with coroutines and get the results of the tasks, how to convert existing APIs to coroutines, how to use coroutines in an Android app, especially together with Architecture Components and, finally, see how to test coroutines.
MAW-7262.title: Coroutines, a new scope

MCK-0102.description:
As we start out on the Android world, we can see how magic unfolds on our phones with just a few lines of code! We love it when whatever we want to build just works, However, as we grow as engineers and start working with teams, we realize that it's not just about "making it work".  Writing code that evolves gracefully is an important skill, that all of us - beginners and experienced developers - can improve every day. 

On this talk, you'll learn about the SOLID principles. We'll discuss them at a high enough level for you to understand that they are applicable to many other software development fields, and we'll have Android-specific examples for you to apply them right away on your projects.
MCK-0102.title: Rock-SOLID Fundamentals for Android Developers

MDP-7925.description:
There is a common misconception that junior developers are a burden and won‚Äôt be delivering value for the first months or even years. Yet after observing not only my own but others contributions to teams while still being junior developers, I realised that even though our technical skills were still developing, our insights were useful to the teams from day one. 

In this session, I want us to discuss some of this misconceptions and help juniors and teams alike understand the real value they can bring to a project or company. Because a good developer is worth hiring no matter their experience level.
MDP-7925.title: The Fake Problem with Junior Developers

MEE-2432.description: Mobile apps have evolved over the years and there is many components to starting a new projects and having working and maintainable software. This talk will discuss what components need to be thought about from the beginning to create a successful mobile app. This will include architecture, unit testing, CI/CD and code quality. So the purpose of this talk is to guide anyone that is starting a new project or has an existing project to what concepts, tools and best practices to use for a successful project. I will be talking about architectures that help with testability of your code. Ill speak about linting tools such as Android lint and ktlint for code to uphold coding styles and develop rules. I will speak about tools that give us metrics and help with pull requests and code reviews on our code such as CodeCov, SonarQube and Code Climate. There will content about CI/CD and its importance in your software cycle and some add-on's that help you automate your software process. Finally ill give some personal learning's about working on a big enterprise team and how important team dynamics is.
MEE-2432.title: What is important when building a mobile app?

MKQ-2052.description: Data binding is great for eliminating boilerplate and keeping UIs in sync with your state‚Ä¶ but there's a lot more that it can do. This talk will take you through the more advanced features of Data Binding, beyond the basics. It will cover using custom binding adapters, two-way binding, animations and testing considerations. Moreover it examines how using Data Binding influences your app's architecture. You'll learn how to get the most out of Data Binding so that you can write less repetitive, safer, efficient apps.
MKQ-2052.title: Advanced Android Data Binding

MLB-9655.description:
Let me tell you a simple story that happened in your project. You started the project and you created your mother activity class, MotherActivity, which inherits from AppCompatActivity. In this class you implement generic behavior for all your activities.  
Then one day, after creating your tenth activities with the same toolbar, you created ActivityToolBar that inherits from MotherActivity and factorizes the toolbar code in a single class.  
Awesome: Factorization by inheritance.  
And you keep going this way. Then you created LocationActivity that inherits ToolBarActivity and is able to provide the device location without more code to daughter activities.   
Nowadays, you have a graph of mothers classes in your project and it‚Äôs a real nightmare; you have ten different types of those classes with code replication because Java doesn‚Äôt allow multiple inheritances.  
Perhaps your story is more about fragments. Perhaps you have the both fragments and Activities.  
Did you now that a nice, simple and elegant solution exists which bring back summer in your code (at least for the activities inheritance river of tears).  
And guess what, the answer is just in the conference room.
MLB-9655.title: Activities or Fragments: A solution to the inheritance nightmare

MNH-6684.description:
Something lurks underneath the surface of most digital images you deal with.

You may have looked at the detailed information for some photos you‚Äôve taken and found a lot of information, such as what device they were captured on, and what the device settings were. Apps like Lightroom and Google Photos seem to magically know where your photos were taken.

But where does that information come from? Where is it stored, and how? We will get you through the nitty gritty of the Upside Down of photographs, find out what metadata is, how it is stored and all the many formats you can find in the wild. From there, we‚Äôll be able to take a short tour of the ExifInterface 
support library, and understand why it was created to replace the other ExifInterface.
MNH-6684.title: Meta, meta, meta! What the EXIF is image metadata

MOE-9463.description:
In-app navigation has always been one of the most overseen complex tasks. Android developers have either created their own solutions or relied on 3rd party libraries, to handle navigatiion from one screen to another. The new Navigation Component from the Android team provides a well-integrated solution to this problem.

You will learn from my experience using the Navigation Component, and I will compare it to Conductor, another popular framework that I‚Äôve been using for the last years. We will also explore some of its downsides, some edge cases that the documentation does not cover, and how we can solve them.

This talk is for Android developers with experience that haven‚Äôt used the new Navigation Component yet, and beginners who are yet not familiar with the different patterns for navigation, both groups can greatly benefit from it.

Come to learn how the new Navigation Component can help you create rich routing experiences with ease, including deep linking, in-app navigation and common patterns like BottomNavigationView.
MOE-9463.title: Smooth Sailing with the Navigation Component

MRL-6766.description: Learn everything there is to know about the latest Android App Bundle distribution model.
MRL-6766.title: Android App Bundle: the New Distribution Model

MSW-0013.description:
Pendant longtemps, les Threads, AlarmService,(Firebase) JobDispatcher, etc. vous ont permis de r√©aliser des t√¢ches en arri√®re plan. Cependant chacune de ces m√©thodes ont des inconv√©nients soit au niveau des pr√©-requis de l'appareil (API ou pr√©sence de Firebase), soit au niveau de la quantit√©, de la complexit√© ou maintenabilit√© du code.
Lors de l'I/O 18, Google a annonc√© une nouvelle biblioth√®que : Le WorkManager ! Int√©gr√©e √† Jetpack, elle propose une fa√ßon standard et unifi√©e de g√©rer vos t√¢ches en arri√®re-plan. Est-ce que cela va enfin vous permettre de simplifier votre code ? De rendre plus stable votre application ? De faire revenir l'√™tre aim√© ? C'est ce que nous verrons... :)
MSW-0013.title: Simplifier la gestion des t√¢ches lourdes avec le WorkManager

MUL-0027.description: Do you fear changes in the shape of a monster legacy code base? Do you have zero test coverage and don‚Äôt know how to regain safety in your day-to-day work? Come to this talk and get insights from the developers of a million client SDK who solved this problems without a whole rewrite.
MUL-0027.title: Test the untested - our journey from zero coverage to automated testing

MVB-6859.description:
Are you still using VideoView because its "simple"?  Or, "gasp" sending . a media Intent to take the user out of your app? Are you sick of bugs where it works on some devices, but not others?
Exoplayer "2" the Rescue. 
Exoplayer2 gives you a consistent, high quality, multimedia experience that supports a variety of Codecs and streaming standards. The online examples look difficult (because they are) üò¢ Let's prove it isn't! üôå You will write a video player with Exoplayer in minutes that plays Streaming and Downloaded content. Promise ü§û.
MVB-6859.title: Exoplayer 2 rescue VideoView

MVE-6873.description:
Most modern architecture patterns (and especially Clean Architecture) rely on five basic principles known as the mnemonic acronym ‚ÄúSOLID‚Äù.
Knowing and applying these principles leads to more maintainable code, better readability and many more benefits!
In this talk, these 5 principles will be explained and applied with Android App development in mind.
MVE-6873.title: SOLID principles for Android developer

MZI-8147.description: When does a mobile app become enterprise? When it contains thousands of lines of business logic? Or when it brings good profit? I stick to the idea that solid test coverage makes a mobile app enterprise  At Shopify, developers spend no less efforts writing tests than writing business logic. Being open to new technologies we quickly adopted MVVM (with Android Architecture Components), Kotlin (with Android Extensions) and more. In this talk, I‚Äôll share our experience using those tools and specifically present some patterns we use when building and testing Shopify Point of Sale app using MVVM.
MZI-8147.title: MVVM Testing Patterns

NCZ-9956.description:
Augmented Reality (AR) is booming on mobile with ARCore / ARKit and new tools are emerging for building awesome experiences.
This talk will introduce you to fundamental concepts of AR before diving into ARCore and see how to use it to build a simple AR app on Android.
After looking at the basics, we will focus on what ARCore can offer us to build advanced AR apps with the following tools:

- **Cloud Anchors**: create a multiplayer AR app where both Android and iOS users can collaborate. The users will be able to interact with a 3D object simultaneously.
- **Sceneform**: a 3D framework that let you build advanced AR app without all OpenGL boilerplate. Use OBJ, FBX, or glTF 3D assets to render your 3D models and bring your Android UI components in AR.

___Live demo will be shown during the talk and after to highlight all the capabilities of ARCore on Android.___
NCZ-9956.title: Unleash the power of AR with ARCore and Sceneform

NES-1499.description:
Durant ce codelab, nous allons d√©couvrir les bases du langage Kotlin.
En quelques mots, ce langage moderne permet de coder des applications tournant dans l'environnement Java, Android ou directement en natif. En plus de cela, il int√®gre tellement de sucres syntaxiques et de concepts absents en Java qu'il donne un coup de vieux √† ce dernier !.
Vous allez voir, c'est un langage trop top qui vous fera oublier le Java ;).
NES-1499.title: D√©couvrons le langage Kotlin

NIZ-9897.description:
Android is not only for regular mobile apps - it can be used to make self-service Kiosks as well. 

You will learn from my experience of leading the development of Android-based self check-in Kiosks about the challenges of locking the system to run single app and blocking any security holes or stability issues.  You'll learn about how to architect the remote maintenance and management infrastructure for Android-based single-purpose applications in a mission-to-Mars autonomous environment and what to expect from Google's new Android Management API (now in BETA). We'll talk not only about the software, but also about the hardware and UI/UX side of creating Kiosks and the unexpected challenges and bottlenecks ahead. You'll leave the talk knowing about the peculiarities of the emerging field of COSU (company owned single use) devices and will be prepared to tackle them heads on when having your next Kiosk project on Android.
NIZ-9897.title: Locking, blocking and rocking Android for Self-service Kiosks

NKR-7626.description:
Let me tell you a story. I used forecast Api since 2013. I created the ForecastYahooRest project to show case my vision of an Android architecture.  Unfortunately, yahoo forecast Api was shut down few months after. So I migrated the project to Google forecast Api and updated the application with this new data model. Again Api were shut down in 2015. For the conference I gave at DevoxxFr 2016 I reshaped the project to show up to date good practices in architecture patterns. Unfortunately, the data model migration was a real problem.  I never find out the solution to nicely migrate the data model. It was a red hard wall of bricks and not enough courage to restart from the ground...  
...Until 2018, when I opened again this project to implement JetPack. And this Api migration was a bless for the project. 
I will give you the tricky parts of this architecture which is not really in the code but more in the way to think your code. I will focus my talk on Room, LiveData, ViewModel and Retrofit but I will also talk about architecture and some killing features (like ActivityAddon, StateViewDrawable, ExceptionManager...)  
Create a Forecast app with the last good patterns, github is ready
NKR-7626.title: 2019:Make Android Application Great again

NOG-9878.description:
Lorsque l'on travaille sur une application mobile, on se focalise surtout sur l'architecture, l'impl√©mentation des fonctionnalit√©s et √©ventuellement le design.
Or lorsque l'on travaille dans une entreprise avec un d√©partement Marketing, ou simplement si l'on veut optimiser l'usage d'une app, nous sommes syst√©matiquement confront√©s √† l'impl√©mentation des analytics dans notre code. Et cela peut vite tourner au cauchemar si l'architecture de l'application n'y est pas pr√©par√©e ou si le plan de tag n'est pas bien pens√©. Nous verrons ici comment bien architecturer son app pour pouvoir les ajouter sans _tordre_ son code mais √©galement comment bien d√©finir les √©v√®nements et valeur √† remonter.
NOG-9878.title: Les analytics c'est bon, mangez-en !

NOV-6900.description:
Faire du code Kotlin plus propre et s√©curis√© : outils d'analyse de code // Cleaner and safer Kotlin code : Static analysis tools for Kotlin

Vous perdez du temps dans vos PR pour du code mal formatt√© ? Vous avez des fonctions qui font des milliers de lignes ? Vous voulez v√©rifier la qualit√© de votre code mais vous ne savez pas comment ? Il serait peut √™tre temps d'analyser votre code !

Android Lint, Sonar √ßa vous dit quelque chose ? Mais connaissez vous ktlint et detekt ?

Dans ce mini talk nous verrons des outils pour am√©liorer la qualit√©, la lisibilit√© et la s√©curit√© de votre code Kotlin; comment auto-formater le code, avoir des stats sur la complexit√© du code, trouver les bugs potentiels et o√π modifier et am√©liorer ce code; et aussi comment automatiser tout √ßa dans une CI.
NOV-6900.title: Faire du code Kotlin plus propre et s√©curis√© : outils d'analyse de code

NQE-0463.description: Modeling a domain with functions is a surprisingly effective way to share an organization's business rules with a wider audience of stakeholders than just the tech team. This talk will show you how to express an Android app domain as a set of types and transforming functions and show how Kotlin can help to communicate that design effectively across your organization.
NQE-0463.title: Functional Domain Modeling in Kotlin

NRT-7635.description: The paging library offers a complete solution for efficiently displaying large lists of data but adopting such a comprehensive library can be daunting.  In this talk, I‚Äôll cover some of the lessons we learned while gradually migrating from a RecyclerView.Adapter, populated from a tightly coupled domain and presentation layers, to Paging library. You‚Äôll learn about the main components of the Pagining library, where they fit in your architecture, how decoupling the UI and the data/domain layers results in more maintainable & testable code. You‚Äôll understand which DataSource type you need for your use case see how you can display multiple data types in the same RecyclerView and how to handle other use cases like interactions with a view item, deleting or inserting an item, selection states or showing section headers. Learn from our experience how to migrate to paging and the benefits we saw.
NRT-7635.title: Migrating to Paging library

NTE-5380.description:
Let‚Äôs face it, we waste a lot of time on things that don't add any value. Maybe you use the same pattern in different places and copy&paste the same files over and over. Probably the same happens whenever you create a new app or module. What about all the time that you spend in Jira or other tools on tasks like moving tickets or logging time?. What if you could automate all that? Well, you can, and I‚Äôm going to show you how by writing your own Android Studio Plugin.

In this talk you will learn how to create a new Android Studio Plugin using Kotlin, create templates to generate code automatically, write live templates to insert frequently-used constructors in your code, easily integrate Android Studio with Jira or other tools, create a brand new full App in minutes using feature modules and much more.
NTE-5380.title: Write your own Android Studio Plugin and automate everything

NXW-8654.description:
Do you have a database in your application? Is it a Realm database? Then this talk might be for you.

In this talk you will learn : 

* The basic differences between Realm and Room
* The motivation behind migrating to Room
* How to migrate to Room step by step

By the end of this talk you will be able to migrate a Realm database to a Room database in no time!
NXW-8654.title: From a Realm to a Room!

NYI-1720.description:
`Android` developers are facing a common problem: how to test our applications on many devices without sacrificing too much time or money?

    How to build and test automatically our applications for each commit?
    How can we find those devices inside the company, whatever its size may be?
    Could there be a directory somewhere that lists those available devices?
    Could we use a device remotely and share it with other developers as if it were in the cloud?

What if you could answer all these questions with the help of a low cost device farm that fits into a pocket? A pocket full of clouds‚Ä¶

Poddingue, our proposal, aims to tackle this problem thanks to Docker, HypriotOS, Armbian, Gitlab CI and OpenSTF. It‚Äôs an internal solution made of OSS readily available, but it has not yet been publicly announced as a whole.

This is a feedback about an idea on its way to production, a long journey full of different feelings.

At the end of the talk, you should know how to build your own cloudy pocket farm of Android devices and how to use it to test your applications within your ci pipeline.

And as I am cheap, you will also be surprised at how little money you need to build it.
NYI-1720.title: The Android device farm that fits in a (cloudy) pocket

NYN-9651.description:
What's our main complaint when we use an application?

* Speed!
We all expect speed. We want to access everything from the point of our fingers and we want that as fast as possible. When an application is taking to long to open or process some data I bet you also feel the urge to search for another solution - or just to throw your smartphone against the nearest wall in despair. And while you think about this, you‚Äôre looking at that never ending spinner‚Ä¶ that... it just doesn't seem to go away.

* Google Play and the App Store are full of similar solutions... Why should I bother to keep using this one?
We can make all sort of optimisations on our code - and yet, sometimes, we can't really make that process as fast as we wanted. There are always some constraints that we can't really avoid - device limitations, network, server, etc. but we can create the illusion of speed - a visual aid that keeps the user busy while, on the background, we are processing his action.

Yes. Time is relative and we want the users to feel that every action is as responsible as possible.
NYN-9651.title: Perception of Speed

NYT-0062.description: D√©couvrons ensemble les nouveaut√©s de Kotlin 1.3 dont les inline classes, les contrats, la s√©rialisation, la stabilisation des coroutines et autres nouveaut√©s succulentes.
NYT-0062.title: D√©couvrons les nouveaut√©s de Kotlin 1.3

NYY-0011.description:
So, you've decided to split your application into separate modules. Now, how to manage dependencies between them? Dependency injection, that's how.

By injecting application-scoped resources into your Android components, you can build fully independent and testable modules. This presentation will use Dagger 2 to generate the implementation of the injection, but the basic principles are applicable without it, therefore no extensive knowledge of Dagger is required. After setting up the injection, we'll see how it can be manipulated in practical cases to control the application's behavior.
NYY-0011.title: Cross-Module Injection

OAZ-9406.description: Ah la carte SIM ... on en a tous une voir deux. Comme tout dispositif √©lectronique, on a vu sa taille se r√©duire au fil des ann√©es, jusqu'√† pouvoir √™tre aujourd'hui _quasiment_ d√©mat√©rialis√©e. En commen√ßant par un rapide historique de la carte SIM, son r√¥le, et ses √©volutions, cette pr√©sentation d√©taillera le fonctionnement de l'eSIM (embbeded SIM). Nous verrons que cette technologie est subtile au point qu'il soit possible d'avoir une "eSIM" amovible üò≥. Enfin, nous ferons un tour du cot√© d'Android Pie pour voir comment le support de l'eSIM y a √©t√© introduit.
OAZ-9406.title: De la carte SIM √† l'eSIM

OCQ-8597.description: Clean architecture is a well-known architecture for structure software systems, in this talk, you will see how to can implement clean architecture within Android's app and how to take advantage of Kotlin coroutine to simplify the asynchronous implementation
OCQ-8597.title: Clean Architecture with Kotlin coroutines

ODA-3499.description:
Do you exactly know what's your app doing when you deliver it to your users? Are you 100% sure? Would you bet on this? You're probably confident with the code you wrote and you know what is doing. 

But what about the code that others wrote? 

We pull dependencies from the online repositories every day. Our applications strongly rely on external libraries that are hosted on public Maven repositories. What if one of those library contains some malicious code? Imagine a library that starts harvesting your user data without you knowing it.

In this talk we will see how to monitor and protect your application from malicious dependency on the web that might end up in your final compiled App.
ODA-3499.title: I have no idea what my app is doing ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

OFS-3054.description:
Refondre en profondeur l'application PagesJaunes, tout en assurant ses √©volutions et sans repartir from scratch, revient √† changer le moteur d'un avion en plein vol. 

# Contexte
Depuis sa cr√©ation, de nombreux d√©veloppeurs ont contribu√© au code, chacun avec sa mani√®re de d√©velopper, ses principes, ses bonnes ou mauvaises pratiques... Nous sommes alors arriv√©s √† un point o√π la maintenabilit√© de l'application √©tait devenue critique. Nous devions r√©agir et mettre en place une architecture unique et adapt√©e √† la dimension de notre application.

# Sujets de la pr√©sentation
Nous sommes partis de la clean architecture comme base de d√©veloppement de l'application.
Nous avons r√©pondu √† plusieurs solutions essentielles dans le d√©veloppement android aujourd'hui :
1. Quelle place pour nos activit√©s/fragments
2. Responsabilit√© des vues
3. Le r√¥le du ViewModel
4. La communication entre nos couches

Pattern ViewHolder, lives data et RxJava ne sont qu'une partie des technologies retenues pour r√©pondre √† ces questions mais encore faut-il savoir comment les utiliser ensemble.
OFS-3054.title: Design Patterns : Clean Archi + MVVM + Asynchronicit√© - REX sur une migration r√©ussie

OHU-7663.description: Google's introduction of Android Things shook the market. This talk starts out by looking at the architecture of the platform, and dives in deeper and deeper into the hardware side of things. Attendes can look forward to oscillograms, analysis and various other aspects covering the "electrical engineering" side of Android Things. When done, attendees have a solid grasp of how to interact with Android Things, about how to connect additional hardware and about how to leverage system services efficiently.
OHU-7663.title: Electrical Engineering with Android Things

ORI-1193.description:
In the past 5 years mobile apps have expanded to encapsulate almost every instance of our daily lives: we use them to communicate with loved ones, share secrets, and to them we reveal part of ourselves. They interact with almost every business transaction around the world, and with the rise of IOT they are even being connected to our homes and cars. And yet according to surveys only around 5-8% of the world population knows how mobile apps operate or work.

Even though Google and Apple make us ask the user for permission to access sensitive data such as location, contacts and documents, most users do not really understand what they are allowing developers to access. GDPR is a big step forward for user privacy and data security, and yet to most people it just means annoying popups on websites they click away as quickly as possible. 

In this talk we'll see how important it is to earn your users' trust in a time when we are all worried about privacy. We will be reviewing real life scenarios about information transparency, and how it can be achieved with small changes in design and code. Helping users understand how your app uses their data is good for everyone.
ORI-1193.title: Explain, please: Help your users trust you

OVK-2477.description:
In this talk, we will learn how to build an application with the ARCore Android SDK. We'll start with a quick look at physically based rendering, and how to find or create these 3D models. 

Then we'll learn the basics of adding virtual objects and interfaces to our environment, using the Sceneform library. 

We'll close with Cloud Anchors and Augmented Images, which are used to create collaborative and interactive augmented reality experiences.
OVK-2477.title: ARCore - Basics and Tools

OVM-9319.description: How awesome would it be to be able to build your own smart device? You could be able to instruct it to do exactly what you need it to do, pair it to whatever you want, have full control over it, and so much more. Till now, that wasn't trivial. Android Things though is a game changer and just recently got its first stable release. Without almost any extra knowledge, you can now build pretty much anything you can imagine! And what if you want to make it voice triggered? And what if you don't want to say "Ok Google" every time you want to instruct it? And what if it should understand many instructions? Not a problem! During this talk we will explore how we can build our own smart, voice controlled device
OVM-9319.title: Building your own IoT assistant

OXW-9944.description:
Jouer √† des jeux, c'est bien, en faire c'est encore mieux, surtout gr√¢ce √† Kotlin et libGDX. Construisons ensemble un casse brique et profitons-en pour faire un tour du framework de jeu libGDX.

Cette session montrera le concept global de libGDX, comment afficher et animer les √©l√©ments de notre jeu, la gestion de collisions pour d√©truire nos briques. On se plongera dans des concepts plus avanc√© comme les shaders pour manipuler les pixels de nos images. Tout √ßa pour quoi ? Pour faire p√©ter le high score !
OXW-9944.title: Explose le high-score : construit ton jeu en utilisant libGDX et Kotlin

PAU-3967.description: Authentication is the door through which you welcome your users into your app. Most of them need to know the identity of their users to securely save user data in the cloud and provide the same personalized experience across all of their devices. Fortunately, Firebase takes all the stress out of OAuth tokens, refresh tokens, passwords, encryption, etc. thanks to its Authentication-as-a-Service nature. It supports authentication using passwords, phone numbers, popular identity providers like Google, Facebook and Twitter, and more. So all you need to think about is how to integrate it into your app in the most efficient way instead of worrying about doing it from scratch. Firebase Auth provides you with a secure place to handle and merge all your sign-in methods. In this talk, we‚Äôll cover overview of Firebase Auth, its benefits, and go through an example implementation of various sign-in providers using Firebase.
PAU-3967.title: Personalize the Experience: Firebase Auth

PIO-9079.description:
Depuis quelques temps, nous voyons des chatbots partout. D‚ÄôAmazon en passant par Facebook, Microsoft ou IBM, chacun y va de sa solution. 

On consid√®re aujourd‚Äôhui que 25% de la population des √âtats-Unis poss√®de un assistant vocal, et l‚Äôeffort commercial d√©ploy√© de ce c√¥t√© de l‚ÄôAtlantique nous fait percevoir qu‚Äôil en sera bient√¥t de m√™me chez nous.

Du c√¥t√© de chez Google, le Google Assistant est maintenant d√©ploy√© de mani√®re massive via les Google Home, appareils Android et m√™me iOS. Alors comment faire pour se positionner sur ce march√© √©mergent ?

En tant que d√©veloppeurs mobiles, nous sommes souvent identifi√©s comme √©tant capables de faire des chatbots - ‚ÄúC‚Äôest bien un truc de Google non ?‚Äù - alors que les technologies sont de fait assez diff√©rentes.

Ainsi soit-il !

Nous montrerons ici comment faire un premier pas dans ce nouveau monde, en utilisant les technologies de Google pour cr√©er, entra√Æner, tester et mettre en production son premier assistant vocal. Cette mise en bouche, faite par un d√©veloppeur Android pour les d√©veloppeurs Android, permettra de d√©mystifier l‚Äôunivers de ces petits robots qui parlent !
PIO-9079.title: Les chatbots pour les d√©veloppeurs Android : garantis 100% SANS Android

PJX-9369.description:
Quand on parle d‚Äôaccessibilit√©, on pense automatiquement aux rampes d‚Äôescaliers, ou aux places de parking. Mais qu‚Äôen est-il de l‚Äôaccessibilit√© des applications mobiles ?
Cette pr√©sentation fera un tour des pr√©conisations aussi bien UX/UI que techniques. Comment savoir si je dois utiliser un contentDescription ou un labelFor, quelle est la taille id√©ale des cibles tactiles (d'ailleurs c‚Äôest quoi une cible tactile ?), quels indices rajouter √† mes interfaces, quel ratio de contraste de couleur ? LTR vers RTL, comment g√©rer ? Comment utiliser TalkBack ? Et toutes ces questions que l‚Äôon peut se poser (ou que l‚Äôon ne s'est pas encore pos√©es) l√©gitimement.

Rappelez-vous de Gandalf qui se cognait partout dans la petite maison de Bilbon Sacquet, le hobbit. La maison con√ßue pour des Hobbit par des Hobbit, n‚Äô√©tait pas du tout adapt√©e √† Gandalf qui faisait  votre taille.
Quand on con√ßoit / d√©veloppe une application, cela ne demande pas plus d‚Äôeffort de cibler un plus large public‚Ä¶encore faut-il savoir comment.

Ce talk est justement pour tous ceux qui souhaitent en savoir plus √† ce sujet, pour faciliter l'acc√®s √† l'information √† une plus grande partie de la population.
PJX-9369.title: L‚Äôaccessibilit√© sur Android en 2019

PKT-1741.description: Building an app that does something useful is necessary but not sufficient for success on the Play Store. In this talk we'll discuss some auxiliary features you can incorporate today that greatly improve your app's chance of success, and show some real life examples of doing so.
PKT-1741.title: Putting it all together: features to maximize your app

PMO-6673.description: Avec les m√©thodes de d√©veloppement actuelles, avoir une plateforme d'int√©gration continue est un besoin vital. Si dans de nombreux domaines il s'agit de quelque chose d'√©vident, on se rend vite compte qu'il y a encore des lacunes lors du d√©veloppement d'application mobile. Peu de documentations, des contraintes mat√©rielles, des gestions de tests uniques,... L'environnement de developpement Android ne facilite pas la t√¢che! Mais il ne faut pas perdre espoir, car c'est tout de m√™me possible! Sur un exemple simple utilisant les outils les plus courant (Jenkins, Sonar), je vais montrer que l'on peut avoir un syst√®me automatis√© avec int√©gration, livraison et d√©ploiement continue. Je vais aussi pr√©senter comment nous avons palli√© au probl√®me des tests sur t√©l√©phone pour nos usages.
PMO-6673.title: Profiter de l‚Äôint√©gration continue dans ses projets Android

PNJ-3689.description:
Learn about all of the time-related APIs in Android
  - How is time represented in Java
  - What are the available APIs to get it
    - Difference between AnimationUtils.currentAnimationTimeMillis, SystemClock and System
    - Time base (boot time, epoch, etc.)
    - Time evolution (monotonic, CPU-based, etc.)
    - Accuracy vs precision
  - Why/when all of this is important : mostly caching or task trigerring
  - Listen to time change
    - ACTION_TIME_TICK
  - How to display a time/date? And why it matters
PNJ-3689.title: A Brief History of Time

PRH-7615.description:
Your relationship with RxJava doesn't have to be complicated. We find many ways to use it wrong; it is also powerful when used properly.
In fact, RxJava can guide you in shaping a sound architecture for your app. We only have to follow a few but decisive principles.

In this talk, we'll:

- See how side-effect isolation can help avoiding bugs.
- Learn how to model your data and share it as one unique stream between your view and your presenter.
- Discover the ways a unidirectional data flow makes adding new functionality easy and safe.
- Look at we can easily deal with collateral side effects, such as navigation.

After this talk, you‚Äôll be able to write a robust and reactive architecture for your app, taking full advantage of RxJava.
PRH-7615.title: Effective Rx

PRX-5289.description:
Nous savons √† quel point une passe graphique peut √™tre compliqu√©e lorsque nous tentons de suivre les maquettes au pixel pr√®s. Il arrive bien souvent que le d√©veloppeur doive d'ailleurs modifier le rendu sur mobile par rapport aux maquettes, en accord avec la conception.

Ceci se traduit souvent par un nombre important d'allers-retours et de compilations des apps √† r√©p√©tition pour modifier d'un point la taille d'une police de caract√®re. Et m√™me l'instant run prend du temps et force le designer √† √™tre √† c√¥t√© de la machine du d√©veloppeur.

Tout cela va devenir du pass√© gr√¢ce √† Cockpit : cette biblioth√®que permet d'apporter des modifications en live sur le smartphone, comme changer la couleur du background, augmenter la police, etc. sans avoir √† toucher √† votre IDE.

Via un menu de d√©buggage qui appara√Æt sur votre smartphone, Cockpit va vous permettre de changer le design de vos applications sans avoir √† recompiler le projet, et √† distance de votre machine. 
C'est simple, intuitif, et il est m√™me possible de laisser le p√¥le conception "jouer" avec pour revenir vers le d√©veloppeur avec les meilleurs param√®tres.
PRX-5289.title: Facilitez le d√©collage de votre application  avec Cockpit

PSM-6312.description: Photography is a powerful art form that you can use to share experiences, tell stories or simply delight others. I will share with you what I learned after over 10 years of practice. We will study some of my photos (https://www.flickr.com/photos/romainguy/) to learn about composition and exposure rules, when to use them, when to break them. You will also learn a bit about equipment, when and why it matters, and when it doesn't.
PSM-6312.title: The Art of Photography

PTI-3143.description:
FR :
Avec l'augmentation des risques de cybers√©curit√© sur les applications mobiles, il devient n√©cessaire d'adapter nos m√©thodes de d√©veloppement sur Android.

Nous allons voir comment chez Orange, nous sommes pass√©s de DevOps √† DevSecOps :
- am√©lioration de l'Int√©gration continue
- mise en place d'audits de s√©curit√©
- Maintien en Condition de S√©curit√©
- veille

Nous ferons ensuite un focus sur MobSF, solution automatis√©e Open Source d'analyse statique et dynamique tout-en-un.

EN :
With the increase of cybersecurity risks on mobile applications, it becomes necessary to adapt our development methods on Android.

We will see how in Orange, we went from DevOps to DevSecOps:
- improved Continuous Integration
- implementation of security audits
- Maintenance in Security Condition
- watch

We will then focus on MobSF, an automated  all-in-one Open Source solution for static and dynamic analysis.
PTI-3143.title: How we went from DevOps to DevSecOps on Android with MobSF at Orange

PWC-1055.description: Let's be honest. Till 3 years ago, adding motion to your app was probably the last thing to be implemented IF it would be implemented at all. The main reasons were 2; A. it was a pain to animate the simplest thing and B. the feedback your users were expecting was an annoying dialog window for all the useful... and sometimes not so useful information. And that was fine! The last couple of years and after the introduction of the material design principles, this is not the case anymore. The users expect some meaningful feedback about their actions, that will not interfere though with the flow of their interaction and it will be "normal" to the eye. Very recently, Google unveiled a lot of new, amazing tools that can help you take your app to the next level, engage your users more by offering a meaningful and fun experience, without causing you headaches anymore
PWC-1055.title: I like to move it, move it

QCH-8558.description:
Even though Android is a mature platform by now, the adoption of Kotlin at Google I/O 2017 brought about a sweeping wave of freshness and enthusiasm amongst developers. Regardless of what the language and design patterns we use when writing an app, there is only one way to ensure correctness and quality: testing, static analysis and continuous integration.
Many still think that setting up a CI for your project is hard, onerous, and not that useful, but we‚Äôre going to see how this is not true. Focusing on static analysis and unit testing, we‚Äôll walk through setting up a continuous integration pipeline for a modern open source Android project using Gradle, CircleCI and Kotlin. We‚Äôll see what benefits this brings to a codebase and how with a few tricks we can make sure external contributors adhere to the project code style, how we can prevent subtle bugs to sneak into the codebase, all with very little effort and zero budget.
QCH-8558.title: Computer Says No ‚Äî¬†Static analysis and CI in a Kotlin world

QCL-2762.description:
Almost everybody is moving away from monolithic codebases towards modularized codebases. This modularization process has its own problems and difficulties but when we add Dagger into the mix, all of the sudden everything seems more complicated. Do I use subcomponents or components? Do I use Dagger or Dagger-Android? How can I use scopes in a proper way? We usually don‚Äôt ask these question but rather copy other‚Äôs people implementation without understanding what Dagger does behind the scenes.

In this talk you will learn how you can use Dagger and Dagger-Android to help you to implement dependency injection in your multi-module project but, most importantly, we will also deep dive into the internals of Dagger and Dagger-Android to understand how they work internally. Hopefully, by understanding their internals you will be able to make informed decisions about the different approaches that Dagger and Dagger-Android offers you.
QCL-2762.title: Multi-module dependency injection with Dagger and Dagger-Android

QGW-2102.description:
The stereotype of the lonely developer working by themselves, without communicating with anyone is a myth. We work in teams. We work with people: other developers, or designers, product managers, project managers. Other people.

We underestimate the work it takes to build a good team. A team that functions and is productive, a team that solves problems, a team that knows how to communicate, and that completes tasks. We even underestimate how many skills each person has to learn to make the team function.

With this talk I will explain the different cycles every team goes through, what constitutes a good team, what skills are needed and what the most common mistakes are that make teams fail. Attendees will walk away knowing what actions and skills they will need to work on to make their team better.
QGW-2102.title: The myth of the lonely developer

QHE-4395.description: Clean architecture is one of the hottest topics in the Android world right now, but still there's no One Right Way to write clean apps. And there shouldn't be -- as long as the code is clean‚Ñ¢Ô∏è, everything is fine. In this talk I'll try to explain the core concepts of clean architecture, so that you don't need sample projects, examples or references anymore. Instead, you'll know how to tell if a code follows clean architecture, how to avoid popular mistakes, and how to think to make writing clean code a breezee.
QHE-4395.title: A practical guide to thinking Clean

QIW-9288.description:
Until now, in order to perform background work in Android, developers had to choose between multiple execution options. At Google I/O 2018, the Android team launched WorkManager as part of the Android Jetpack. This library provides a simple and clean interface to specify deferrable, asynchronous tasks and when they should run.
The presentation will include an overview about the existing background solutions, what‚Äôs happening behind the scenes and why and when we should use WorkManager. Also, we will discover details about the architecture of the WorkManager library and about the main components(Worker, WorkRequest, WorkManager, WorkInfo) of it. Finally, we will highlight how to use WorkManager for scenarios like chained sequences of tasks that run in a specified order, unique named sequences, tasks that pass and return values and how to apply constraints in order to decide when to run the task.
QIW-9288.title: Workout your tasks with WorkManager

QJF-9797.description:
New architecture components and concepts are always fun to setup for your new shiny application. But it's never easy when it's about making it in our existing apps. We never have time, it's not the right moment or ... it's too risky :(

Let's sit together and see how we can unlock features one by one for improving our app.

This workshop proposes to rework an application step by step for injecting new principles:

- Android architecture components & immutable states management 
- clean architecture projection with functional Kotlin aspects
- testing for real
- advanced dependency injection with Koin
* bonus with coroutines

all of this will be written in Kotlin, RxJava

Requirements: Laptop with AndroidStudio 3.2+, Kotlin plugin
Knowledge: Kotlin, RxJava
QJF-9797.title: Reshape your application with a Clean MVVM Architecture

QMW-7145.description: If you‚Äôve used Firebase Performance Monitoring, you know that it automatically discovers and reports performance metrics for all the HTTP transactions in your app.  But have you ever wondered how it does that?  Android doesn‚Äôt provide any APIs to listen in on an arbitrary connection (that would be a security problem!), and Firebase supports URLConnection, Apache, and OKHTTP APIs.  The secret here is bytecode manipulation at build time using the Transform API provided by the Android build tools.  Join this session to find out how the Firebase Performance Monitoring Gradle plugin intercepts and measures HTTP transactions at runtime with some assistance from bytecode manipulation at build time.
QMW-7145.title: (Android) Transformers - bytecode in disguise!

QUH-2644.description:
This talk will teach developers how to efficiently write & setup experiments (A/B Tests) and hence showcase a way to create apps that keep the customers at the centre of everything. 

If you attend this talk you will learn how to frame the hypothesis, calculate runtime of an experiment, set up metrics to measure success so that you can act as a product manager yourself in future!  

Think of this talk as a crash course for Mobile Developers to become Product Owners.
QUH-2644.title: Customer Driven Development : What, Why & How?

QUR-1430.description:
When you adopt the Android App Bundle, you get size savings through config splits and feature modules. That‚Äôs just the beginning!
This talk is about the advanced features that the Play Core library enables in your application  when you adopt the Android App Bundle: on demand modules, in-app updates, etc..
I‚Äôm going to use some sample based on my experience working with the Play Core library and supporting the Android developer community adopting these new feature
QUR-1430.title: The Core behind the Bundle

QVB-9671.description:
Building concurrent, multi-threaded applications is hard. The approach we've taken today relies upon sharing memory and managing mutable state. It requires us to manage expensive resources like threads and memory locks.
Kotlin takes a different approach. It introduces a concurrency model that offers an easier and more efficient way to manage concurrent operations. This talk guides you through Kotlin's concurrency model and it's concurrency primitives, and how you can take advantage of them in your applications.
QVB-9671.title: Concurrency in Kotlin -- Not your typical Concurrency Model

QYP-2650.description: Two longtime friends with complimentary skills meet a new mobile SDK for building high-performance apps from a single codebase, what could go wrong? Flutter is quite powerful but with great power comes great responsibility. Using widgets, building a meaningful UI in a new way, finding that library we need and getting used to a different architectural approach are some of the many challenges we face as developers and designers when going into the cross-platform world. In this talk we'll review some of this advantages of using Flutter, how to tackle common challenges when adopting it and how can it spark a better collaboration between designers and developers, including roles and responsibilities, a well-defined feedback process and our own experience while building an app. Interested? let's chat it over a beverage of your choice.
QYP-2650.title: Flutter, a designer and a developer walk into a project

RBP-6855.description:
You've been working as an engineer for a while, and now you want more. More responsibilities, more decision making power, more money. But where do you even start? Become an engineering manager right? Not so fast. 

In this talk, we'll go over how to choose the best career path for *you*. There are many ways of becoming the leader you know you deserve to be, and not all of them are obvious nor conventional. We'll cover the different options and the skills required to get there, but we'll also talk about why *not* to become a manager, or even a tech lead.

Finally, you decide to make the jump. You "made it" right? But, now what? How to become the best leader you can possibly be? How to give constructive feedback? How to set expectations with your people? And what's next? Keep climbing?... or choose to go back to building.
RBP-6855.title: Becoming a Leader in Tech: How to boost your career without losing your mind

RBU-3913.description:
What‚Äôs that Flutter everybody in mobile development is talking about these days? Another new thing that will be forgotten by this time next year or a true revolution in mobile apps development? Is it really worth my time?

Flutter is Google's mobile SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organizations around the world, and is free and open source.

Beyond the commercial pitch, in this codelab you will create a simple Flutter app and discover the features that make Flutter one of the most pleasant and productive development platform.

You need to bring your own laptop and validate the following steps :

* https://flutter.io/docs/get-started/install
* https://flutter.io/docs/get-started/editor
* https://flutter.io/docs/get-started/test-drive

The demo app is running on your simulator? Let's go with Flutter!!!

NB: We can speak in French or in English.
RBU-3913.title: Write your first Flutter App

RDK-7687.description:
Ready to start building the Internet of Things, but aren‚Äôt sure where to start?  Android Things enables you to use familiar Android development tools to build smart, connected devices.

Exciting? Yes!

However, if you're lacking in hardware experience you might feel a bit overwhelmed. That's the position I was in when I picked up my first Android Things development kit.

In this talk, you'll go from 0 to ready to build with Android Things including:

- what hardware & tools to use?
- just what exactly do all those I/O acronyms mean?
- how to install & update the OS?
- how to build and deploy a simple new project?
- what new & familiar tools/libraries can you leverage to build exciting, smart, connected devices of your own?
RDK-7687.title: Hello Android Things

REB-6912.description:
In this session, we'll cover how elevation works on Android. From an overview of the available APIs, seeing what is new in Android P, and getting to the nitty gritty of how shadows are rendered on HWUI and Skia. Lastly, we'll learn how to take advantage of the existing APIs and work within their limitations to obtain original and unique results.

This talk follows the track of existing blog article(s) on the topic: https://blog.usejournal.com/playing-with-elevation-in-android-91af4f3be596 and another upcoming article. There is also an open source app, Uplift, which will be used to showcase the effects as we talk about them: https://github.com/rock3r/uplift
REB-6912.title: Uplift ‚Äî Material shadows on Android

RFV-4717.description: Kotlin is now everywhere, we should all be using it and it is required for all current job specs. But is it really accessible to anyone? There are quite a few annoyances, from using the wrong set of brackets (or the right ones the wrong way) to annotations like @JvmSuppressWildcards @JvmField and other types of magic that make Kotlin not as simple as we were initially led to believe. Is it Kotlin right for everyone?
RFV-4717.title: What I find annoying about Kotlin

RLL-1310.description:
Are you tired of decrypting the JUnit test that you wrote a few weeks back? 
Do you want to write nice, readable & structured tests that are actually fun to write and joy to read?

If you have answered yes to at least one of the questions above, I have a solution for you. Join this talk and fall again in love with unit testing.

We will cover:
- Describe how Spek works
- Comparison with JUnit 
- Sample tests for a project following a clean architecture pattern (data, domain & view layer)
RLL-1310.title: Structured unit testing with Spek

RML-8658.description:
En bons passionn√©s de d√©veloppement mobile, nous voulons tous que notre application soit belle, fluide et bien con√ßue. Mais la r√©alit√© nous rappelle souvent que le temps est limit√©, et qu‚Äôil va falloir faire les bons choix. Aussi, √† quel moment r√©alise-t-on que, malgr√© toutes nos bonnes intentions, l‚Äôon part dans une mauvaise direction ?

Au cours de cette pr√©sentation, nous allons vous partager comment une √©ch√©ance dans notre roadmap nous a amen√©s √† prendre plusieurs jours de recul alors qu‚Äôil nous fallait justement acc√©l√©rer la sortie de notre produit. Le temps de faire un audit de notre propre code, prototyper une autre impl√©mentation, la partager en interne et l‚Äôexp√©rimenter pour s‚Äôassurer du gain attendu. 

Si nous avons exp√©riment√© cette d√©marche dans le contexte du nouvel outil de contr√¥le de billets des agents de la SNCF, nous sommes convaincus que vous pourrez l‚Äôadapter √† vos propres projets.
RML-8658.title: Prendre son temps pour aller plus vite

RWW-7478.description:
Kotlin's momentum in the Android community has been growing steadily over the last year, and a transition from Java to this new language is now a viable and attractive choice for many development teams.

For myself, I'm an iOS developer, and I've had a first hand experience with such a transition, because our community has now almost entirely shifted from Objective-C to Swift.

And there is a great opportunity for us to share experiences across platforms because in both instances, developers are being introduced to a new language that allows for some very interesting and powerful constructs (like first-citizen function types, sealed classes, infix functions, type extensions, etc.) that we just had never seen before.

So my goal with this talk is to share with you all of the tips and tricks that my colleagues and I have come up with while learning Swift, and show you that those translate very well into Kotlin, and can bring a lot of safety, expressivity and declarativeness to your code!
RWW-7478.title: What a Kotliner can learn from Swift

RXE-0594.description: Marc est un grand technophile et √† la pointe de la technologie, mais Marc est malvoyant. Comment moi, demain, si je fais mes prochaines applications en Flutter, puis-je permettre √† Marc d'utiliser mon application sereinement ? Explorons les outils mis en place par Flutter pour r√©pondre √† cette probl√©matique.
RXE-0594.title: Ok, Flutter elle est o√π, la rampe d'acc√®s ?

RYN-8134.description:
When it comes to accessibility support, it can be difficult for teams to know what to focus on and how to get started. Sometimes it can be hard to justify the effort when teams think it only benefits a "few" users, which is a debatable assumption. Whether you're new to the subject or you're keen on knowing more about it, this talk is for you.

In this talk, you will learn how supporting accessibility helps in a lot of different cases, from temporal illnesses or reversible situations to severe disabilities. Moreover, you will learn how people use different Android accessibility services such as Talkback or SwitchAccess to interact with your application in a different way. We will also explore the current range of developer tools that can be used to spot potential accessibility issues in our apps. 

And finally, you will learn how developers, designers and product managers can work together to make sure that we create experiences for everyone.
RYN-8134.title: Is your app for everyone? A primer on accessibility for Android

SAI-8739.description:
‚ÄúThis is my invariable advice to people: Learn how to cook- try new recipes, learn from your mistakes, be fearless, and above all have fun!‚Äù - Julia Child.

The path of becoming a senior Android developer can be very similar to the one cooks take to become chefs. 
The software we create is the expression of our knowledge, of what we‚Äôve learned, and our own experiences. The same can be said about chefs and the food they create.

In this talk we are going to analyse and learn from the journey cooks take to become chefs and apply it to our own craftsmanship. We will be able to understand the set of skills that are needed to become a good chef, the struggles they go through in each step of their journey, and how similar they are to us, to our journey as Android developers. I want attendees to learn what it takes to be a good Android developer, what it means to be junior, the fears we've all faced when we started, what it means to be a senior developer, and finally how to lead a team successfully.
SAI-8739.title: The Android Chef

SCS-0941.description:
Kotlin changed the way we code!
But did you already adapt the way you test?
The language offers new possibilities but also offers challenges, just think of Coroutines.
Let's write nice and clean Kotlin tests together.
SCS-0941.title: Effective Unit testing with Kotlin

SGL-5141.description:
We all heard about TDD: test driven development.
It produces better code and less bugs.
But in our daily android lives, why aren‚Äôt we doing it?
Is it possible to develop an android app fully test driven? Where do I start?
Should we only test java classes? Should we use or avoid Robolectric?
SGL-5141.title: TDD on Android, why and how

SIJ-4158.description:
"If PiP'in was easy, everyone would do it."üï∫

Picture-in-Picture is a feature Android introduced officially on all devices since Android Oreo (and some Nougat), but only a handful of apps actually use it. Most of those Apps that do arrrrrreeeeee.... Google Apps or applications built by device manufacturers. 
Why? ü§î It seems like it would be a great way to promote media, features, and engagement with your application by keeping users in your app longer. Give your app the ability to serve your users with pertinent information while they accomplish other tasks.

It is because there are a lot of issues once you start actually working with it. Opportunities to cause crashes, lost backstacks, locked-out users and so many other issues come forward. In this talk, we will cover how to use Picture in Picture, but also what those issues are, why they happen, how you can handle them, how are other apps doing it, how some apps are completely failing, and more importantly WHY so many things you rely on as an Android application developer just DO NOT WORK!
SIJ-4158.title: PIP'in ain't easy, how to handle Picture in Picture to create rich media experiences

SQA-4508.description: MVC, MVP, MVVM, Android Architecture Components, Android Jetpack, Clean Architecture, modularisation, tant de concept autour d'un m√™me sujet, le d√©veloppement architectural d'applications Android. Ce talk pr√©sente les architectures pass√©es et pr√©sentes pour tenter de faire les meilleurs choix pour l'avenir en fonction de votre projet !
SQA-4508.title: Android Architecture Overview

SQI-7010.description:
The Android Developer is an amazing creature that you can find freely in the wild. You can easily spot one by either having fun writing brilliant poems on Kotlin and telling everyone how this new language is a game changer or by swearing at some specific Android device that does not follow the documentation as it should.

We've taken a long path since the dark ages, where most devices were dominated by a greyish popup saying that an application has stopped. We now have a stable OS, a lot of API's and libraries that allow us to easily build our application foundations and finally testing is gaining the strength and importance that it deserves.

Nevertheless, there's still things to worry about - and fragmentation is on the lead! It's one of the most time consuming issues that are easily reported, and honestly, the most frustrating one. No one wants to spend more time looking for an undocumented solution than implementing the feature itself. 

On this talk I'm going to present a couple of... lets go with the word "challenges" - that I've faced in the past years to solve the above problems. The do's and don'ts and a list of swearing words that I've come up to.
SQI-7010.title: The Daily Life of an Android Developer

SUF-3682.description:
Sharing is a very important part of any app. Having users that love your app/content enough to share it with their friends means a great success. And it‚Äôs a very good way to spread the love, get new users.

In order to ensure an excellent user experience, your users need to land on the right content with no extra effort. Here comes deep linking. When used together with Firebase Dynamic Links, deep linking is a very powerful tool that provides seamless user experience.

Just when you think it can‚Äôt get any better, it does - Instant Apps! It allows users to have a taste of your app before even installing it.

In this session, we‚Äôll focus on using deep linking with Firebase Dynamic Links and see how Instant Apps can be used to improve the user experience.
SUF-3682.title: Improve the Experience, Instantly

TCI-9863.description:
Depuis plusieurs ann√©es, l'int√©r√™t pour le Machine Learning ne se d√©ment pas et les clients sont aujourd'hui pr√™ts √† int√©grer cette technologie dans leurs produits. Mais comment et quand en faire usage sur mobile, et quels sont les enjeux quant √† l'int√©gration du Machine Learning ?

Pour r√©pondre √† cela Tensorflow Lite, petite soeur de Tensorflow, vous permet d'ex√©cuter des mod√®les appris par ML sur des appareils mobiles avec faible temps de latence. Vous pouvez ainsi en tirer parti pour effectuer une classification, une r√©gression lin√©aire ou toute autre op√©ration de votre choix sans n√©cessairement devoir subir un aller-retour vers un serveur.

Il devient ainsi ais√© de d√©porter l'intelligence du Machine Learning sur un terminal mobile. Les possibilit√©s pour une entreprise sont de fait d√©cupl√©es : Tensorflow lite permet enfin √† un utilisateur final de modifier en temps r√©el et hors-ligne un mod√®le ML, pour obtenir par exemple des suggestions personnalis√©es, ou recevoir des comparaisons de produits.
TCI-9863.title: Tensorflow

TCT-1480.description:
Navigating between screens is pretty simple right? No it‚Äôs not. Actually not all the time.
Last year Google introduced Navigation Component tool helping us standardise the design and the implementation of how screens can pass in front of the Android users.

We started to use it with my team last summer and we learned a lot about its benefits, and its pitfalls. In this presentation, I'll try to give a feedback about what we learned, what hope you can put in it and what‚Äôs not to expect from it.

Here is an outline of the talk:

- The Navigation Component tool and API
- Testing your navigation
- Specific use cases
    - Handling multi start points
    - Handling custom transitions and Shared Elements
    - How to handle other entities than Fragments
    - Handling the back navigation
- Implementing the navigation logic
    - 3 examples of implementation patterns we found
    - Alternative example to Navigation Components
- The lib is in alpha, what is it implied by this, for real
- Single or Multiple activities what to choose?
- Integrate nav controller in an existing app
- Conclusion
    - What can it bring to your app?
    - Should we use it?
TCT-1480.title: Navigation Component, feedback from the trench

TGV-6847.description:
Is your team not reviewing code? You should be! Does it feel like you could be getting more out of code reviews? Absolutely! Code reviews are severely underutilized.  Let me show you some approaches to get more value from code reviews for you and your team.  

I will emphasize code review best practices starting with why you should be performing code reviews.  Some teams don't perform reviews and this is really hurting them in the long run. I will attempt to sell the review process and explain why it is fundamental to our roles as developers.  

Teams that are performing reviews may feel burdened by doing so and see it as chore. This also is not ideal and I will dig a little deeper and discuss why we feel this way sometimes. What are the strategies to overcome this feeling? Is it possible to enjoy code review?

Are there shortcuts to work more efficiently at reviewing code? Absolutely! Can some things be automated? What can't? Let me show you some great approaches to making the review process streamlined and efficient.
TGV-6847.title: Getting the most out of code review

TJG-2729.description:
Durant cette pr√©sentation, nous allons vous montrer la puissance d'**Android Slices** au sein de l'application Android de **Pages Jaunes** utilisant la Clean Architecture.

Nous vous expliquerons comment nous avons int√©grer les Slices. Pourquoi nous pensons que ceux-ci vont finir par remplacer **Deeplink** √† termes, et ce que sont impl√©mentation peux √©ventuellement vous apporter üöÄüí∞
TJG-2729.title: # Death of Deeplink on Android ?

TOL-6808.description:
La d√©l√©gation de l'authentification √† un service tiers apporte un nombre consid√©rable d'avantages aux d√©veloppeurs ainsi qu'aux utilisateurs finaux.
OpenID Connect et OAuth2 sont deux standards c√©l√®bres dans le domaine de l'authentification et l‚Äôautorisation. Je vous propose une pr√©sentation permettant de bien comprendre leurs bases et ainsi les adopter efficacement dans vos futurs applications. Nous verrons notamment une d√©mo avec le SDK AppAuth.
TOL-6808.title: OpenID Connect et Oauth pour les n√©ophytes

TQJ-1021.description:
Vous avez cr√©er votre **architecture** mais vous continuer √† perdre un temps consid√©rable ?
 Comment s'assurer du respect que votre √©quipe respect votre architecture lors de cr√©ation de nouvelle pages

Comme vous pouvez d√©j√† trouver les templates de **Google**, nous allons vous pr√©senter comment l'impl√©menter un Plug-in dans **Android Studio** peut vous √©pargner du temps ‚è∞
TQJ-1021.title: Stop au gaspillage ! Votre plugin est l√†

TSH-5340.description:
The fast pace in the mobile industry places great demands on companies to deliver highly modular and functional products. Developers need to support their clients with everchanging UI and business logic requests, and this requires a fundamental change in the way we approach mobile development.

How do you utilize your resources to achieve maximum efficiency and reliability, without sacrificing your team‚Äôs time and sanity? How do you push updates without having to release a new version of your app?

In this presentation, you will learn how you can eliminate business logic from mobile and transfer it to external services, allowing focus on beautiful client-side applications while securing your clients‚Äô business needs. We will list crucial points in the development process of such a framework using only native components. Finally, you will walk away with greater insight into improving your development process and keep your team happy and productive.
TSH-5340.title: Adaptive Android - a Lego approach to building native apps

TUK-6441.description:
Not everyone agrees on what makes code awesome. However, it's important for a team of developers to establish conventions and common goals.

In this presentation, I'll explain how we established in our team of 7 Android developers a method for defining the standards that we want to set for the application's code. This method serves both to resolve disagreements and to document the motivations of our decisions. I'll provide examples by going over some of the points that we put in our own "definition of awesome code".

Working together on defining a standard encourages consensus, clarifies the reasons for conventions, and serves as a location for everyone to share best practices.
TUK-6441.title: Definition of Awesome Code

TUS-7781.description:
Nombreuses sont les solutions, √† l‚Äôimage de Couchbase Mobile Realm ou encore Firebase, permettant d‚Äôassurer un m√©canisme de synchronisation de donn√©es entre des appareils mobiles et un backend. Si celles-ci r√©pondent g√©n√©ralement correctement √† ce besoin, il peut parfois s‚Äôav√©rer n√©cessaire de souhaiter impl√©menter soi-m√™me ce type de solution (par exemple pour avoir quelque chose de parfaitement ajust√© √† ses besoins en termes de conso de batterie/r√©seau).
Durant ce talk je passerai en revue les principes d‚Äôarchitecture n√©cessaires pour mettre en place ‚Äúfrom scratch‚Äù un tel m√©canisme. Du design de l‚ÄôAPI aux d√©tails de l‚Äôimpl√©mentation du client, en passant par les strat√©gies de gestion de conflits et le monitoring de l‚Äô√©tat de synchro : tout vous sera pr√©sent√© !
TUS-7781.title: Architecture de synchronisation de donn√©es entre une application mobile et un backend : mode d‚Äôemploi

TWY-4180.description:
Working with a design system can be hugely rewarding: layouts can be created and modified using shared components. This should result in faster development and consistent designs across the app. But getting there is a slow and painful process.

When implementing a design system you have to make many decisions, like: Where do you start? What actually makes a component? And how flexible should components be? This talk will shed some light on these issues by taking you through Deliveroo's process of adopting the design system in its three Android apps.
TWY-4180.title: Consistency is Key - Working with a Design System

UFK-5733.description:
Mobile moves fast, and so do you. To meet your deadlines, you want to build the right thing, at the right time; every time.

Your continuous integration pipeline allows you to do this, but can it do more?

- How can you enforce coding formatting, styling conventions, and best practices?
- Do you build everything on every commit? Do you have a daily build or customize your build per branch?
- What do you record and analyze? Are your tests passing? Do your screens look correct? Is your apk getting too large?
- How do you distribute your apk for testing and release?
- How do you track, record, and notify quickly when issues arise?

In this talk, you'll what tools are available at every step of the continuous integration pipeline; allowing you to automate as much as possible and dedicate your time to what matters most.
UFK-5733.title: Automate All The Things!

UGK-1528.description:
