Six months ago, we decided to change our apps business model, as way as rethink our navigation and interactions. It was the perfect moment to also rethink the design of our application. 
From the first drafts by our  designer to the publication of our 2.0 version, this talk will come back on our experience on redesigning an existing app with legacy code (and screens), with focus on the best (and the not so good) practices, and the lessons we learned from this.
UGK-1528.title: The big makeover

UIB-7280.description:
Android est l'OS mobile le plus utilis√© au monde. Il est utilis√© sur √©norm√©ment de produit.
La plupart d'entre vous ma√Ætrise le d√©veloppement d'application mais connaissez vous les √©tapes n√©cessaire au portage de cet OS?

Voyons ensemble ce qu'il faut faire pour porter l'OS de Google sur une nouvelle cible √† savoir une Raspberry pi 3.
UIB-7280.title: Portage d'Android sur une Raspberry Pi 3

UNS-3300.description:
We all know how important theming is for an application. Themes define our application and give some meaning to it. Every application in its life time goes through a change of theme whether
  1. It's a redesign
  2. Introduction of a new flavor
  3. Add support for multiple themes or,
  4. Provide seasonal personalisation (eg: Christmas or Diwali season).
And we are well aware of the pain this causes. Every time one of these requirement pops up we try to find a solution that can generalise the whole theming process. In this session, we will talk about the power of attributes and an approach that can help avoid the problem of making extensive changes to an app for theme updates and provide easy personalisation. It will also encompass the details about changing the theme of the application at runtime with minimal changes done to the codebase in no time. By the end of the talk you should have a clear understanding on how to provide quick personalised look, add multi theme support and update themes in a SNAP!
UNS-3300.title: Be like Themos, Add/Update themes in a SNAP!

VCE-4539.description: Have you always wanted to try out developing apps (or Actions) for the Google Assistant but immediately looked way when you saw that the official client library was in Node.js only? Fortunately for you, dear Android/Kotlin lover, Google has launched the Java/Kotlin client library earlier in January (written in Kotlin!) and if you'd like to learn how to develop for the Google Assistant using Kotlin, you should come to this workshop!
VCE-4539.title: Write an Action for the Google Assistant with Kotlin

VDC-4578.description:
Want to just focus on the business logic more rather than the implementation logic while building a feed list with comments and replies? 
Want to implement this much faster than you imagined and make it easily maintainable? 
Well, dive in to check how I utilized AirbnbEng‚Äôs Epoxy library and data-binding to bypass the need for adapters, view-holder classes, and the Diff Utils for a feed listing app.
VDC-4578.title: Epoxy‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäA proxy for Adapter and complex view types!

VDR-6609.description: Vous avez d√©j√† entendu parler du Kotlin ? Peut-√™tre que vous trouvez le langage cool mais que vous ne savez pas comment l'apprendre ou comment migrer l'un de vos projets ? Ce talk vous donnera des r√©ponses et vous aidera dans vos r√©flexions !
VDR-6609.title: From Java to Kotlin

VJG-9207.description:
ConstraintLayout is a popular library for UI development on Android. It is deeply integrated with the Android Studio design tools, allowing developers to quickly create complex and reactive UIs. We recently released ConstraintLayout 2.0, which brings even more layout capabilities, virtual viewgroups, performance improvements and flexible ways to organize your UI. More uniquely, the library also provides powerful animation and motion handling capabilities via MotionLayout, a subclass of ConstraintLayout. All together, this new declarative approach makes it very easy to create modern, motion-enabled UIs for your application.

This talk will cover the new capabilities of the library, common pitfalls and solutions to UI patterns, performance aspects, integrating motion, and how to best take advantage of the library in your own application via a series of use cases and examples.
VJG-9207.title: ConstraintLayout 2.0

VOJ-6007.description:
You want to style the title of dialogs throughout your app and you think it should be simple enough. However, once you dive into it, you might start asking questions - should I use alertDialogTheme or alertDialogStyle? Should I use windowTitle or dialogTitle? It is no secret that the styling and theming system in Android is complex, but I promise there is some method to the madness! We can avoid writing custom components just to achieve pixel perfection if we know how tame to the beast.

In this talk, we will learn about the difference between themes and styles, the hierarchy of different styling techniques and how to use them effectively. We will also learn how they work internally, and the best practices of how to apply them. We will wrap up by discussing the newest app theme in town - the Material Components Theme and the attributes that come with it, like ‚ÄúcolorOnSurface‚Äù.  

At the end of this talk, you will know how to style your app like a pro with the correct use of Styles, Themes, TextAppearance and sensible defaults while specifying colour, shape and typography through Material Theming.
VOJ-6007.title: Styles, Themes, Material Theming, Oh My!

VOK-7028.description:
Developer tools for pixel pushing are one of the more under-developed areas when it comes to Android. Pixel pushing itself is such a tedious process that eats up a lot of development time. Some teams are lucky enough to utilize tools like Figma and Zeplin, which help reduce time when translating designs into something tangible. Others still use the tried and true method of using redlines, screenshots, and photoshop! 

In this talk we'll go through the journey of pixel pushing, the pain points, and some tips and tricks to help developers and designers speed things up. We'll then talk about Window, a new tool to help you master the art of pixel pushing.
Window is a new free open source tool with the goal of enhancing the process of pixel pushing.

First is the Window Android App. It lets developers and designers measure, add rulers / grids, and verify placement of what you're seeing on screen. 

The second is the Window Android library, to integrate into your projects. This library lets you export your Android UI and view it tools like Figma & Sketch. 

We'll talk about how you can integrate two tools to help you simplify your workload and speed up development time!
VOK-7028.title: A New Window Into Pixel Pushing - Discussing new tools to help developers save time when implementing designs!

VQS-5461.description:
Writing multi-threaded software is hard. Debugging and chasing down problems like deadlocks, race conditions, and memory leaks is even harder.
Kotlin takes a different approach. It doesn't have to be so hard. Learn how you can write concurrent and asynchronous software using coroutines. And stop sharing memory to communicate mutable data. Leverage channels to safely communicate across coroutines.
VQS-5461.title: Concurrency doesn't have to be hard: Kotlin Coroutines and Channels

VTN-7485.description:
Comment cr√©er un syst√®me capable de stocker et partager des fichiers de mani√®re s√©curis√©e dans une architecture Zero-Knowledge (sans faire confiance aux serveurs) ?

Comment g√©rer le chiffrement de fichiers volumineux et les droits d'acc√®s distants ? Quelles sont les principales limitations ? etc...

Au travers d'un projet concret (aujourd'hui utilis√© par des millions d'utilisateurs), il vous sera d√©taill√© l'architecture choisie et les d√©tails techniques permettant son impl√©mentation c√¥t√© client et serveur.
VTN-7485.title: Stockage et partage s√©curis√© de fichiers volumineux

VUR-7482.description:
Even among machine learning experts, we have encountered many myths about on-device machine learning:
1. Android is not powerful enough for machine learning
2. Machine learning is not for me, it‚Äôs for people with PhDs
3. Machine learning requires a lot of data - millions and billions of samples.

In this talk, Hoi will bust some myths with live demos and introduce best practices for developers to get around the reality of building everyday ML use cases including barcode scanning, AR stickers and more, on Android. Also, some core Android functionalities might surprise you‚Ä¶ in a good way.
VUR-7482.title: Myths and Reality of Android Machine Learning

VWI-6435.description:
Le backend for frontend est un concept d‚Äôarchitecture, apparu il y a quelques ann√©es, qui sugg√®re d‚Äôexposer chaque frontend √† un unique backend d√©di√©, r√©pondant sp√©cifiquement √† ses besoins. Nous commencerons par pr√©senter les forces d‚Äôune telle architecture dans le cas d‚Äôun d√©veloppement mobile. 

Nous nous int√©resserons ensuite aux stacks pertinentes pour r√©aliser un tel backend, et plus sp√©cifiquement √† la plus avantageuse pour les d√©veloppeurs Android, Kotlin avec le framework Ktor. 

En utilisant la capacit√© de Kotlin √† compiler vers plusieurs plateformes, nous montrerons qu‚Äôil devient alors possible de factoriser certaines parties de la codebase entre des projets Android & iOS. 

Et si la th√©orie vous convainc, mais que vous restez sceptique sur la mise en pratique, nous partagerons avec vous notre retour d‚Äôexp√©rience sur la mise en place de cette d√©marche dans un de nos projets client.
VWI-6435.title: Kotlin multi-plateforme, l'arme fatale du backend for frontend

WEK-5855.description:
You have probably already used the Drawable at least one time in your life, it‚Äôs almost everywhere if you build an Android app. But, do you know everything about the Drawable? How to add a text on it? What can we use to do a Drawable? Is it efficient to use this?

At Citymapper, we are using Drawable for several purpose, but mostly to show more informations to the user in a small amount of space on the screen, but how we‚Äôve done this magic trick?

I‚Äôll answer those questions and speaking more about the wonderful world of Drawable during my talk !
WEK-5855.title: The wonderful world of Drawable

WIU-2749.description:
Considering how consuming REST APIs can be costly in terms of data and number of calls especially in cases where doing this frequently can hamper the speed at which our apps deliver these responses it is then imperative to make sure our users get the required experience when using our apps. GraphQL is a query language for our APIs that allows us to query just the data required by the clients.
Using GraphQL would immensely solve a lot of problems when it comes to retrieving related data from multiple REST API endpoints by directly reducing the multiple queries to just one query. In the our present world where speed is often a mark of quality service, it is therefore important for we developers to provide this in our applications by leveraging on the power of GraphQL.
WIU-2749.title: GraphQL for Android; No REST for the wicked

WLQ-5551.description:
Deploying an Android app to the play store always contains some cost in it. Furthermore the user isn't always keen to download (again) our latest versioned app. How about doubling the cost of development with the iOS app into account (or Web)?  
At Square, we came up with a system in which the server owns the workflow of the client. This means the client doesn't know before hand which screen, which image or text it's gonna show next.

In this talk, we'll:

- Know why Square ended up choosing this system.
- Discover how we built it.
- Look at the challenges, the pros and cons of such an architecture.
- Talk about how we want to alter it for the future.

Attendees to this talk will be expose to solutions for problems every company is facing but don't address.
WLQ-5551.title: Server Driven UI Workflow

WRN-8138.description:
Almost all meaningful apps retrieve data from some sort of API. The shape of the data that this API returns is out of the client‚Äôs control. At Upside Business Travel, our data is constantly changing form. These changes require client updates to stay up-to-date with the latest data models we receive from our APIs.

How do we ensure that previous versions of our app don‚Äôt break when the data model changes? Will missing expected pieces of information break our app? How can we be confident that custom views always receive the data they expect, no matter where they are being used in the app? 

In this talk, I will explore how we use the benefits of Kotlin, data mapping, and ViewModels on our Android team to protect our app against both expected and unexpected data model changes.
WRN-8138.title: Protect Your App from Unexpected Data Model Changes

WVN-8830.description: In this experiential talk, Mohanraj Karatadipalayam gives you a detailed overview of his personal journey of building native mobile apps in Android and iOS using Kotlin/Swift with Redux and Rx Libs. He explores in detail, the need of these libs and how these libs can change the developer experience, where the app code becomes more predictable and testable. Using real examples and code snippets, Mohan highlights key challenges encountered while writing such apps and how he overcame them. He also outlines the benefits of building such apps to mobile development teams.
WVN-8830.title: Redux + (RxKotlin | RxSwift) == Awesome Native Mobile Apps‚Ää

WXM-8643.description:
As Android developers in the modern age, we're spoiled for choice when it comes to asynchronous tools: RxJava, LiveData, Kotlin Coroutines and now with AndroidX, ListenableFuture! But how do these architectures scale? How easy is it to onboard new developers? How performant is it?

In this whirlwind expedition, we'll adventure in search of fantastic async solutions to your concurrency problems, spending time to discuss how to implement a flexible, scalable architecture for your application, big or small.
WXM-8643.title: Fantastic Async and Where to Find Them

WZR-4043.description:
The correct handling of timezones & locales is one of the most under-appreciated parts of software development. Commonly known as a part of i18n, a lot of people underestimate the impact that getting it wrong can have for your users as well as your systems.

Drawn from experiences with working on a global network of backend systems, websites and mobile apps in more than 30 locales for the last 10 years, this talk will provide an introduction to the concepts behind time zones and locales.

You‚Äôre going to learn about the history of time measurement and time synchronisation and how the world eventually ended up with the global system of time zones of today. Today‚Äôs model is full of interesting and sometimes outright bizarre quirks and you‚Äôll look at some of best and worst of them.

Technical topics covered are:

* Time on the JVM and Android
* What level of support and libraries do we have for Java and Kotlin?
* Ways to make your developer life supporting multi-lingual/-locale apps easier.
* "WHAT? We have to support daylight-savings-time?" 
* Managing user expectations

Eventually, it will be revealed why a whole country skipped a day and what they gained from going through this :)
WZR-4043.title: Why a Whole Country Skipped a Day: Fun with Timezones and Locales

XAB-5925.description:
The introduction of Android Architecture Components made things are easier for the less experienced developers. However, In order to build robust, testable and scalable applications we need more. That's where the Unidirectional Data Flow architecture comes in, borrowed from Flex and Redux on the web. 

The approach is based on the idea of an immutable state that represents the state of our app. All the components are decoupled from each other, and they work together taking advantage of Kotlin's language features. We solve the asynchrony problem using Coroutines, specifically Channels and Actors. 

Do you want to know more? This talk will guide you through our implementation of this paradigm, with clear steps and a detailed explanation that will help you understand its value and spark your curiosity!
XAB-5925.title: Unidirectional Data Flow with Android Architecture Components and Kotlin Coroutines

XAF-6415.description: With the announcement of Android Slices, you can now provide rich, dynamic and interactive content to your users even outside your app! Slices allow you to build content to be displayed in the Google Search app and later in other places like the Google Assistant. Slices can help users perform tasks faster by enabling engagement outside of the fullscreen app experience. In this session, we‚Äôll explore how Slices can help you provide a better experience for your users and see how it‚Äôs implemented.
XAF-6415.title: Want a Slice?

XDD-5248.description:
Artificial intelligence on-device is the future.
With specific chipset capabilities you can improve the performance of your app and resolve privacy and cost related issues.
AI apps tend to be real-time and mission-critical. Many AI-use cases that enhance an experience can‚Äôt afford latency.
Today, a lot of machine learning services have to send your data to the cloud to perform the actual analysis. Now, calculations can be done directly on the phone, with less risk to users of data getting leaked or hacked.
If you‚Äôre not sending data off into the cloud every few seconds, it means users can access services offline and save data. For developers, if the analysis is done on-device, it saves on paying for servers. 

In this session, I will show you how to use HiAI: one of the world's first mobile AI computing platforms with a dedicated Neural-network Processing Unit.
Huawei HiAI Engine easily integrates a plurality of AI capabilities like Computer Vision, Automatic speech recognition and Natural Language Understanding, making the Apps more intelligent and powerful.
XDD-5248.title: Make your app smarter

XEB-2115.description:
Our responsibility as developers is to ship high quality features in a timely manner. But there are many factors which can hinder development: from tightly coupled, untested codebases, to differences between team members in architecture visions and API knowledge, to time pressure. 
We tend to look at app development from one point of view: the code. But the team that writes that code is as important as the code, so we need to work on architecting a good, solid team as well, making sure that we create a common language in the team, a shared vision and an environment where team members learn and communicate freely.

In this talk, I‚Äôm going to cover some of the lessons I learned along the way and show how we, a team of four, applied them in rewriting Plaid - an open source app, initially created to showcase Material Design. We‚Äôll see how intertwined the code and the team were for the project.
XEB-2115.title: Pragmatic crafting

XEH-9547.description: In this talk we'll discuss how to use common UX patterns and clever architecture to build your own personalized suite of reusable components. Armed with these new components, we'll show how easy it is to build a wide variety of apps in a very short period of time.
XEH-9547.title: Leveraging Common UX Patterns to Build More Apps, Faster

XGH-4941.description:
Have you ever had an experience where a small voice in your head prevented you from acting on an idea, stopped you from sharing your knowledge or trying something new, or maybe even made you feel like your achievements were nothing special? 
That voice is more common than you think!

In this talk we will go over the basic steps that will help you materialize, deconstruct and take control of that voice, helping you distinguish the useful bits of information that can help you grow from the overwhelming debris and clutter. You will learn how to notice the early signs of its onset and manage the situation to your benefit. Finally, you will learn to use simple tools that will help you recognize and acknowledge your achievements and help yourself and others fight the invisible menace.
XGH-4941.title: Inhibiting the Impostor

XIB-8286.description: Firebase offers two cloud-based, client-accessible database solutions that support realtime data syncing. In this workshop, we‚Äôll focus on Could Firestore, Firebase's new database solution. Cloud Firestore is an efficient, low-latency database solution for mobile apps that is optimized for speed, security, and offline use. As part of this workshop, we‚Äôll build an app using Cloud Firestore focusing on realtime updates, expressive querying, and offline support. The workshop participants will learn how to read and write data to Firestore from an Android app, listen to changes in Firestore data in realtime, use Firebase Authentication and security rules to secure Firestore data, and write complex Firestore queries.
XIB-8286.title: Firebase Cloud Firestore: Deep Dive

XIJ-9417.description:
ML Kit is the SDK that makes machine learning features more straightforward for the mobile developers to incorporate in their apps. Since ML Kit has been made a core ingredient of Firebase ,its robust ML APIs can be implemented seamlessly in both android & IOS apps like it‚Äôs any other feature such as analytics, crashlytics etc.

The flexibility provided by ML Kit for mobile developers to use On-device or On-Cloud ML Apis as per the use case is quite significant . In this session we will take deep dive in the different ready to use APIs of ML Kit encapsulating the features of Mobile Vision, Google Cloud Vision API, TensorFlow Lite and Neural Network API and also will discuss how custom models can be hosted seamlessly.
XIJ-9417.title: Understanding MLKit offerings in Android

XLN-5456.description:
Nous avons l'habitude de mettre nos cl√©s d'API dans les fichiers Gradle, dans le Manifest ou √† l'int√©rieur m√™me du code que l'on pousse ensuite en production. Or, ce qui est √©crit dans le Manifest par exemple est accessible tr√®s facilement via des outils de retro engineering.

PAS BIEN !

Ces cl√©s sont parfois sensibles, en particulier si elles permettent d'acc√©der √† des APIs priv√©es ou des donn√©es utilisateurs sensibles. Afin d'√©viter que des donn√©es sensibles ne soient compromises, il est n√©cessaire d'en s√©curiser l'acc√®s.

C'est ce que je vous propose de mettre en place gr√¢ce au Native Development Kit (NDK). En utilisant les biblioth√®ques natives, il est possible  de cr√©er des m√©thodes _compil√©es_ en C++ qui fournissent les cl√©s d'API seulement √† l'ex√©cution. Cela rendra la t√¢che des hackeurs beaucoup plus compliqu√©e pour acc√©der √† ces informations. Nous montrerons qu'il est relativement ais√© de cr√©er ces m√©thodes, m√™me pour des d√©butants en NDK.
XLN-5456.title: Utilisez le NDK pour prot√©ger vos cl√©s APIs

XPP-1467.description:
Android apps are not just series of static screens. To create a great app you will have to bring it into life with meaningful, helpful and delightful motion.

However, a good design is not worth much unless it gets implemented correctly. In this joint designer-developer talk we discuss the workflow from the idea, to design and development and all the way to user‚Äô hands. 

We describe when to use motion and when not to as well as selecting the right type and right intensity of motion. We then dive into the best implementation strategies including communicating state, navigation, feedback, tutorial and delightful animations.
XPP-1467.title: Meaningful motion design and how to implement it

XQK-8719.description: *Vector-drawables, 9 Patches, layer-list, multi-densities, screen sizes*: Android provides many ways to use graphical resources in an application and deal with the fragmentation. The goal of this talk is to take a tour of the available resources that developers can use in their application, see what tools Android Studio provides to manage those resources, how these resources are embedded into the APK and what how the framework uses them at runtime.
XQK-8719.title: A resourceful talk about Android Resources

XQT-5940.description:
English TL;DR: It's a stupid french speaking podcast about leeks  ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Si vous ne savez toujours pas pourquoi "Poireau" ou que si mais que vous n'avez pas rigol√© √† la blague la premi√®re fois, ni les 3000 autres fois parce qu'en r√©alit√© c'est pas si dr√¥le, avouons le... Alors viendez, √ßa ne sera toujours pas plus dr√¥le, ni plus intelligent mais vous pourrez dire en sortant: "Je ne sais absolument pas pourquoi j'ai √©t√© voir √ßa", et √ßa, √ßa n'a pas de prix.


PS: √âpisode 6 car on sait tous que le 6√®me est en r√©alit√© le 3√®me !
XQT-5940.title: Android Leaks @Android Makers - √âpisode 6 : Le retour des poireaux

XVO-2305.description:
Recruter des talents dans le march√© de l'informatique rel√®ve aujourd'hui de la gageure, et le d√©s√©quilibre entre l'offre et la demande entra√Æne une forte concurrence entre les entreprises.

Quelles sont les cl√©s pour maximiser les chances de recruter la personne que vous voulez :

- Vaut-il mieux d√©busquer un _senior_ quitte √† le payer tr√®s cher, ou investir sur un _junior_ ? Et comment le former le cas √©ch√©ant ?
- Que recherchent vraiment les candidats dans votre soci√©t√©, petite ou grande, et comment faire valoir vos atouts ?
- Quels sont les m√©dias disponibles pour rechercher des candidats, et comment sortir du lot sur les r√©seaux ?
- Quels sont les points d'attention pendant le processus de recrutement ?

Nous tenterons d'aborder l'ensemble de ces questions en apportant des r√©ponses circonstanci√©es - bas√©es sur des exemples et des chiffres - et nous nous efforcerons de montrer que le recrutement d'un bon d√©veloppeur est encore possible de nos jours.
XVO-2305.title: Recruteurs, d√©veloppeurs, bonne humeur

XWA-9893.description:
Si, il y a 10 ans, √† cause d'un √©cosyst√®me encore en construction, HTTPS √©tait un protocole complexe √† mettre en place, aujourd'hui il semble que c'est l'inverse.

Rejouons l'histoire pour d√©couvrir et comprendre ensemble les diff√©rentes failles de s√©curit√© qui ont pouss√© le Web √† passer sur HTTPS ainsi que les impl√©mentations associ√©es sur Android.

√Ä travers du code et des analyses, impl√©mentons, cassons et s√©curisons ensemble du code r√©seau pour comprendre comment nous en sommes arriv√©s aux impl√©mentations actuelles.

Nous d√©couvrirons ensuite les limitations de 2019 : pouvons-nous emp√™cher tout le monde d'analyser notre traffic ? Qu'est-il possible de faire aujourd'hui, quels sont les risques pour l'utilisateur, le d√©veloppeur, l'entreprise ? Quels sont les outils et bonnes pratiques pour emp√™cher ou au moins ralentir et complexifier nos analyses r√©seau par des personnes malicieuses ?
XWA-9893.title: S√©curiser ses appels r√©seau Android, de 2009 √† 2019

XXN-3928.description:
When writing networking code, you want to make sure the code between the client and server implementation is consistent. After spending hours defining the APIs with your backend engineers, you‚Äôll probably need to spend even more time implementing those details over to your code (and guess what‚Ä¶ your backend engineers will be doing the same!). This process is boring, time consuming, and prone to errors.

Wouldn‚Äôt it be cool if this process were automated? If you could have classes and interfaces that mirror your API definition? And if they were automatically tested and ready to use out of the box?

It can be done! At Yelp, we define our APIs using Swagger Specs and we successfully automated the generation of our networking code for both servers and clients (iOS & Android). On Android, we generate Kotlin Data Classes and Retrofit APIs that mirror our spec files and are ready to use for all engineers. In this talk, we will explore how we set up our code generation pipeline and how you can start doing it, too.
XXN-3928.title: Let me write your networking code!

XYF-6012.description:
We afraid to use new tech in production. Because we don't know how to properly make error handling. Because we lack experience of solving complex tasks with it. Because we are anxious of lifecycle integration.
This talk is going to rid of these fears for Kotlin Coroutines. Being a powerful tool, it may provide the ease of  concurrency and not bring any additional issues. How to do that? We're covering it in this talk!
XYF-6012.title: How to use Kotlin Coroutines in Production and sleep well

YCY-4899.description:
We love our faces.
We take care of our faces.
But we're not fully exploiting the potential of communicating something to our smartphone using only the face.
Imagine how much the inclusiveness of your application could increase by introducing visual commands, how many times do you need your smartphone and your hands are busy?
A lot of possibilities open up in the fields of security, social media, photography, health and video games.

During this talk I will show you how to easily integrate into your app interesting features such as: face comparison, face detection, head angle orientation detection, facial expression recognition, face parsing, face attributes recognition, face modeling, beautification, image enhancement and much more.

You don‚Äôt need to be an AI expert, all of this is easy to achieve in a clean end elegant way, using a single mobile framework which works in real-time and without internet connection!
YCY-4899.title: Show me your face: facial recognition made easy for Android

YEF-1378.description:
# UiKit, qui es-tu?

Construire une application, c'est un peu comme construire un jeu de Lego. Pour l'assembler, on utilise des briques de formes et couleurs vari√©es. Pour une application, l‚Äô√©quivalent de ces briques sont les boutons, les labels‚Ä¶ avec chacun leurs propri√©t√©s. Les briques sont fabriqu√©es dans une usine, les composants dans l'UiKit.

##  Avant

Lorsque nous devions cr√©er un nouvel √©cran, il fallait cr√©er tous ses composants.
Si le designer ou le d√©veloppeur √©tait depuis longtemps chez PagesJaunes, il savait quel composant r√©utiliser. Pour les nouveaux arrivants... C'√©tait plus compliqu√©...

## Aujourd'hui

Pour r√©aliser un √©cran, on pioche dans l'UiKit les composants n√©cessaires.
Peu importe l'anciennet√© du designer ou d√©veloppeur, celui-ci sait o√π trouver les composants disponibles et respectant la charte: dans L‚ÄôUiKit.

# Contenu
Les sujets abord√©s dans la pr√©sentation :
1. L'UiKit : designers et d√©veloppeurs mains dans la mains
2. D√©monstration de l'UiKit
3. Les r√®gles d'utilisation et d'√©volution
4. Boutons, Couleurs, Ic√¥nes, Textes... et ensuite ?
YEF-1378.title: UiKit : unifier votre UI

YPU-9099.description:
Devons-nous suivre Google et utiliser les ViewModel + LiveData du framework Jetpack ou alors utiliser Presenter + Interactor de l'oncle Bob ?

Choisissons entre 2 applications identiques qui affichent une liste de stations de ski. Les 2 applications vont utiliser Room et Retrofit pour t√©l√©charger puis persister les donn√©es. L'une utilise des Presenter et des Interactor respectant des principes de la clean architecture ; l'autre utilise des ViewModels, LiveData propos√©s par Jetpack ainsi qu'un Repository.

Nous allons comparer ces 2 applications dans le but d'identifier les forces et faiblesses : 

* Complexit√© du code : Combien de fichiers ? Combien de lignes de code ?
* Lisibilit√© du code : Est-il facile de comprendre le fonctionnement de l'application en lisant le code ?
* Adaptation aux changements : Est-il facile de changer ou d'ajouter des fonctionnalit√©s ?
* Testabilit√© : Pouvons-nous cr√©er des tests unitaires facilement ?
* Marge d'erreur : Est-il facile de cr√©er une fuite de m√©moire ?
YPU-9099.title: Jetpack avec ViewModel + LiveData, Clean Archi avec Interactor + Presenter, que choisir pour mon application Android ?

YQH-2599.description:
We often tend to build products which have the best design principles and top-notch engineered code. However, we forget to design it for the real world. User personas, interaction methodologies, and much more combine to create better User Experiences which results in whether the user wants to stick to your app or not.
In this talk, we will try to understand the importance of UX from an Android Developer‚Äôs perspective and will see where we can improve our UX using non-visual code that is not related to visual code.
Agenda:
1. Difference between UI and UX
2. UX is a whole new domain. What things Android Developer must know?
3. Visual Code vs Non-Visual Code
4. Understanding User Personas to define features
5. Non-visual code that affects the UX
YQH-2599.title: Designing Apps for Real World

YUI-3405.description:
Tout le monde ne d√©marre pas un projet from scratch.  
Fini l'√©poque o√π tout √©tait encore √† faire.  
Souvent on d√©marre son nouveau job avec une base de code qui a d√©j√† quelques ann√©es et a connu quelques tentatives d‚Äôarchitecture.  
Une bon rem√®de c‚Äôest d‚Äôaller vers  la *modularisation*.  
Cette architecture qui nous fait d√©couvrir que m√™me si notre code n‚Äôest pas spaghetti il est souvent monolithique et pas facile √† diss√©quer.

Je vous propose √† travers l‚Äô√©volution du code de Meetic d‚Äôapprendre √† :  
 * Monitorer votre code  
 * Retravailler votre code (surtout legacy) pour le modulariser   
 * √âcrire votre nouveau code dans des modules  
 * D√©placer l'ancien code dans des modules  
 * Extraire des d√©pendances   
 * Injecter ces d√©pendances entre les modules  
 * D√©pr√©cier en douceur l'ancien code

YUI-3405.title: Tout tout pour mes moduuuules, travailler avec son code legacy chez Meetic

YUL-8544.description:
R√©concilier les d√©veloppeurs Android, iOS et Windows !

C'est la promesse de beaucoup de technologie mutliplatform. Certaines sont des surcouche Web, d'autres se disent natives sans vraiment l'√™tre, certaines demandent un dev. √† 4 bras. Qu'en est il vraiment ? Dans cet univers, Kotlin multiplatform nous semble une solution d'avenir qui pourrait faire la quasi unanimit√© des d√©veloppeurs mobiles.

Apr√®s un √©tat des lieux des diff√©rentes solutions, on regardera en d√©tail le fonctionnement de Kotlin multiplatform et la richesse de son √©cosyst√®me.

Un peu de live coding Android et iOS viendra aussi pimenter la pr√©sentation.
YUL-8544.title: Kotlin Multiplatform - Enfin du vrai mobile multiplatforme natif

YYF-6635.description:
Dagger is a complex tool, we can all agree on that. It's also the most performant and scalable dependency injector we have available -- no wonder it's the official recommendation from Google when it comes to dependency injection for Android apps. And yet, we keep looking for simpler alternatives (usually service locators) just so we don't have to deal with it.

Even thought Dagger is complex, it doesn't have to be complicated. It's possible to keep things simple and still take advantage of what it offers at its core. There are many ways to setup Dagger, and believe it or not, some of them are quite simple. The goal of this talk is to present a simplistic approach to Dagger, where we can take advantage of dependency injection with minimal boilerplate and optimum performance. On top of that, we'll be looking in details on best practices and how to ensure you're taking the most out of Dagger.

Join me if you've had unpleasant experiences with Dagger -- or even if you're happy with your current setup -- so we can take a fresh look on how we can work with it. And if you haven't worked with Dagger before, this is the perfect opportunity to get off on the right foot!
YYF-6635.title: It's complicated, but it doesn't really have to be: a Dagger journey

YYX-1324.description:
One Bowl to rule them all, One Bowl to find them,
 One Bowl to bring them all and in the darkness motivate them

Earlier this year, we've introduce **Android Things** to a group of people who for some of them had no programming skills.

Assisted by **Florent Blot**, we're looking for a project using Android Things, we'll show how quickly and easily you can create connected devices for your home.
Today, we'll show you how to create a **Smart Bowl** for your pet at home.
YYX-1324.title: Discover how I forgot to feed Hatchi!

YZC-0613.description:
2018 was the year your average user started to care about data protection. Mainstream media had no shortage of content with new stories about election tampering, GDRP, and data breaches which affected hundreds of millions of users breaking every few weeks. Attacks on our apps will continue to become more frequent and sophisticated; in this session we will present the tools you need to counter them.

This talk will focus on security features available from Google Play Services and Google's SafetyNet APIs. We will see how they allow developers to verify the trustworthiness of the devices their apps run on, as well as examples of how to implement them to improve your app‚Äôs security.

Next, we will share first hand experience of hardening an Android app that handles medical & health records. We will see where patient data had the potential to be leaked to 3rd parties and the measures taken to avoid this.

In this current climate of heightened user awareness we have a responsibility to protect the users of our products, after this session you will be better able to do just that.
YZC-0613.title: Tools for Protecting Your Users‚Äô Data

YZY-1444.description:
With increasing capabilities and usabilities of Android apps  , the app size is also getting increased exponentially. Newer apps are coming in range of 60-180 MBs

While not all the functionalities of app are being used instantly , or by all of the users. What If we get on-demand features , like on-demand movies, on-demand cars(grab). Having this flexibility will allow users to download their favourite app without worrying about size of the app. And thus as an organizatio/owner of the app , we can enable more and more users using our app , and features targetted to them.

App Bundle (available in Android Studio 3.2) provides this flexibility and allows us to minimize the download size of our app as required.Rest of the features will be downloaded when requested.

Other best practices like modularization will further help us in benifitting from App Bundle.

This talk will include  whats and whys about App bundle , How to enable bundling in your app , and how to make that app size smaller.

https://developer.android.com/guide/app-bundle/
YZY-1444.title: App Bundle : Smaller size preferred !!

ZCO-9565.description:
La plupart d'entre vous connait le d√©veloppement et le cycle de vie des applications Android.
Cependant, savez-vous quels m√©canismes sont mis en oeuvre par Android pour isoler les applications les une des autres?
Voyons ensemble tout ces m√©canismes qui permettent de s√©curiser l'OS mobile le plus utilis√© au monde.
ZCO-9565.title: Le sandboxing applicatif d'Android

ZCT-4196.description: Firebase offers two cloud-based, client-accessible database solutions that support realtime data syncing. In this talk, we‚Äôll cover Could Firestore, Firebase's new database solution. It‚Äôs an efficient, low-latency database solution for mobile apps that is optimized for speed, security, and offline use. Cloud Firestore lets you build rich, high quality applications by allowing secure access to the database directly from client-side code. Besides being easy to use, it allows you to use queries to decrease the data usage and increase the security so that you can get just the info you need for your user. When offline, apps remain responsive because the Firebase SDK persists your data to disk, giving the end user an immersive experience. Come and learn how you can use Cloud Firestore to effortlessly build powerful realtime experiences on Android in a faster and more efficient way to bring your products to millions of users without worrying about scaling.
ZCT-4196.title: Create, Store, Synchronize: Firebase Cloud Firestore

ZDM-8801.description:
Une fois rentr√© dans l‚Äôindustrie du d√©veloppement, les challenges de code restent souvent un lointain souvenir des √©tudes, ou dans le meilleur des cas des exercices d‚Äôentretien que l‚Äôon connait par coeur. 

Ces d√©fis ont pourtant particip√© √† forger notre passion pour l‚Äôinformatique, ainsi qu‚Äô√† nous initier √† des concepts d‚Äôalgorithmie et de structure de donn√©es, et parfois m√™me √† nous offrir nos premiers pas dans un langage. Des connaissances qui contribuent aujourd‚Äôhui √† la qualit√© de notre travail. 

Curieux de voir ce que ces d√©fis peuvent encore apporter √† nos √©quipes de d√©veloppeurs, nous nous sommes organis√©s pour participer collectivement au challenge adventofcode.com.

Advent of Code est-il un bon moyen pour s'initier √† un nouveau langage comme Kotlin ? Cet exercice personnel peut-il s‚Äôinscrire dans une dynamique d‚Äô√©quipe ? Ces challenges ont-ils encore des choses √† nous apprendre ?

ZDM-8801.title: Embarquez dans l'aventure Kotlin avec Advent Of Code

ZIN-5872.description: For most purposes we don‚Äôt need to modify our *.gradle files much‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwe add dependencies, modify target and minimum API levels, maybe set up signing configs and build types. Anything more complicated than that, and we end up copy-pasting mysterious snippets from Stack Overflow, without understanding how they work. In this talk I'll cover the Gradle scripts in your Android build, what happens, when and why. We'll also very briefly see how this knowledge helps in using Gradle Kotlin DSL
ZIN-5872.title: Gradle for Android developers

ZNT-7569.description:
So, you‚Äôve built an app. It'd be nice to make some money with it and instead of only charging a one-off purchase price you‚Äôre maybe considering a free app with extra features. Or you might think about a subscription model to create an ongoing cashflow by selling a service. 

Depending on your actual occupation in the Android-ecosystem you might never had the need to look into monetisation of an app. In a nutshell, it‚Äôs a Google Play service - implementation should be smooth and easy and super-straight-forward, right? RIGHT?

In this talk we're going to cover:

- Google's various in-app billing offerings and their differences
- Play Billing and how to implement a working billing flow
- Dealing with subscriptions in your app and the backend
- Testing and 3rd party support libraries like Register and BillingX
- Managing your products in Google Play and Firebase Analytics
ZNT-7569.title: Taking your users‚Äô money: In-app billing from start to best practices

ZPO-7428.description:
Gr√¢ce √† Kotlin/Native, disponible en version 1.0 depuis octobre, il est d√©sormais possible d‚Äôutiliser Kotlin pour cr√©er nos applications back et mobile natives en utilisant un m√™me langage. Mais, en 2019, est-ce d√©j√† une solution r√©ellement viable ? Dans ce talk, nous allons vous pr√©senter un retour d‚Äôexp√©rience sur la cr√©ation de notre application : de la cr√©ation des Web Services avec Ktor aux clients iOS et Android, en passant par l'industrialisation et les tests.

Le futur du d√©veloppeur mobile serait-il full-stack ?
ZPO-7428.title: Kotlin end to end: du client au serveur

ZPP-9970.description:
As developers, more often than not, you have access to fast and reliable internet connection, all day long. But the users you target won't. Limited data plans, unreliable network coverage, commuting : those are real obstacle that your users will see daily. This means that network will only be available at some times, and not necessarily when the user wants to interact with your application.

Our talk will focus on creating a user experience with ‚Äòoffline‚Äô being the default working state, and having access to the internet being a bonus for your users. We‚Äôll see how to design your UI/UX to make offline more than an edge case scenario, as well as how to architecture your application, and which tools and libraries can help you to implement it.
ZPP-9970.title: ‚ÄúMake your app work perfectly offl‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Connection Interrupted

ZQZ-5694.description:
This talk will bring you what it is to be the only the Android dev in a company. 
I will share with you my experiences on building applications from scratch, the maintenance, the code reviews, how to take care of the tech debt, how to keep you up to date the latest development changes.
I will expose the relationship between a PM, a designer and a developer and share with you the pros and cons of a small team.
ZQZ-5694.title: Being the only one Android dev in a company: How To?

ZRE-5134.description: All my tests used to involve users named Alice and Bob. Aged 42. Working at FooBar Inc. ZRE-5134.title: What's the fuzz about Unit Testing

ZUZ-4702.description:
Depuis le d√©but des smartphones, √©norm√©ments de solutions multiplateforme sont apparues. Certaines sont des surcouche Web, d'autres se disent natives sans vraiment l'√™tre, certaines demandent un dev. √† 4 bras. 
De notre point de vue, seul quelques unes valent vraiment la peine d'√™tre √©tudi√©e, et dans ces quelques unes, il y a Kotlin multiplateforme. 

Apres une br√®ve pr√©sentation du fonctionnement du multiplateforme en Kotlin, on se plongera dans le code pour tenter en 3H, de refaire l'application AndroidMakers sur Android et iOS, tout en respectant les standards ergonomiques de chaque plateforme.

Sur la base d‚Äôun repository fourni par nos soins, les participants du workshop aborderont les probl√©matiques suivantes  : 


 - D√©finition du mod√®les de donn√©es

ZUZ-4702.title: Kotlin Multiplatform - Et si on refaisait l'application AndroidMakers en 3H ?

ZXK-5204.description:
Your app used a background service, Android Pie "fixed" your service to...... no longer work. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
